headline: Wouldn't advise anyone to take a job here
pros:
Initial compensation can seem generous
Opportunities to work with down-to-earth people, some people willing to give credit where it is due
Comparatively good health benefits
cons:
IBM has no clear strategy and constantly reinvents itself in shallow ways every few months. In particular, there is absolutely no strategy to the Consulting by Degrees program, although they are trying to reinvent it now. As it stands now, there is a lot of lip service paid to development and training but nothing is done in those regards.

Management communicates that they do not care about employees, beginning from before they even begin. Many consultants have had their start dates delayed last minute and promotions delayed but then management would claim that they weren't delayed (despite evidence to the contrary). Health care premiums get more expensive every year and professional development events are often held at home offices on Tuesday and Wednesday nights, when most consultants are on the road. There is a lot of lip service paid to employee value and professional development, but nothing more than that.

The performance system, despite being "reinvented," still rates you based on your utilization which, in turn, impacts your raises at promotion. If you join in Q4, you will likely hit the bench for the rest of the year and Q1 of the next, which will keep your utilization rate and, accordingly, your PBC low. In the existing system, it is way too easy to be punished at raise time for joining during a slow business time even if it is not your job to sign work.

For a technology company peddling its advanced cognitive and analytics abilities, IBM does not outfit its consultants with modern technology. It does not look good to clients when we drag out clunky laptops that experience constant operational problems to try and sell them on our technical products. Employees are usually only eligible to upgrade computers and phones every 3-4 years, which is far too infrequent. 

IBM Sales & Delivery are incentivized differently and often butt heads when trying to sell work. Sales often result in impossible projects, with greatly reduced staffing plans and impractical timelines and, in turn, the client is upset when the promises made by Sales cannot be realized. This gap needs to be resolved in order to preserve client relationships.

Although improving in recent months, corporate communications remain abysmal. Strategy is rarely communicated to first line managers before it is announced company-wide, key questions about massive organizational changes are not answered by leadership until months after the fact, and there is no single source of truth for basic administrative questions. There is no reason that five different managers should provide five different codes for vacation time.

Your professional opportunities are very hit or miss. The Consulting by Degrees participants, in particular, are often put on testing or project management assistant roles that last up to a year and provide no room for professional growth. There can be some cool work to do on sales bids but usually that work is not billable (so you will be punished for it come review time) and sales work is not for everyone.

IBM leadership always gives the spiel that you can "go anywhere you want in the organization," given that there is someone willing to take you in the new group and someone willing to let you go in your current group. However, even when these conditions are satisfied, leadership will arbitrarily put "transfer freezes" on entire segments of the business for months on end or put down some other red tape. Unfortunately, it is incredibly rare to be able to actually move between groups, even if it is the best move for all parties concerned.

Finally, there are far too many incompetent people that manage to hang on through all of the layoffs. This is due, in large part, to the continuing over reliance on utilization rate to determine an employee's value to the company. An employee can be doing virtually nothing on a project with no capped hours (can bill as many hours as they want) while someone contributes to a $100 million sale with no billable code and their utilization code tanks. By logic, the person who contributed to a large sale is far more valuable than the employee who bills a lot but does nothing. However, in this scenario, the person who contributed to the sale would be laid off before the other. I have encountered far too many Band 8 and 9 consultants who have no people skills, weak management skills and basic gaps in knowledge about Microsoft Excel or Powerpoint.

headline: Going down the pan
pros:
Sage used to be a great company to work for.  Then for a while it was merely good.  Now, it's unfortunately a toxic company whose sole focus seems to be to squeeze as much money out of the customers and reduce costs via the grossly unfair performance management system.

There are some redeeming features.  The wages are around standard for the North East, there is a bonus scheme of up to 20% if you are in a global function, the building and surroundings are nice and you get 5 days where you can go an help out in a variety of charities etc.
cons:
The biggest problem Sage has at the moment is the cloud based strategy that they seem to be trying to force our customers onto.  The half year results seem to show that it's not something our customers want.  There also seems to be an excessive focus on selling, as opposed to giving good customer service and as a result technical support people also have sales targets.  There's been and continues to be a massive brain drain as more experienced people get sick and leave.

The second major gripe is the performance management system.  We were promised that last years "stacked rankings" had been discontinued, but it has become apparent this is not the case.  This means that you always have to have some people in the lower part of the scale, which means an immediate performance improvement plan.  I've luckily avoided this so far, but I'm aware of people who in no way could be said to be not doing their job being put onto these, which is unfair and causes unnecessary stress.  Perhaps Sage does have a performance problem, I don't know but introducing such an arbitrary way of marking people down is terrible.

Another side-effect of the performance management is that it encourages negative behaviours amongst colleagues with people sacrificing others to save their own skin.  As you'd imagine it doesn't make for the best working atmosphere at times.

The company has also become extremely top-heavy.  Almost weekly we get a new VP or EVP of something or other and people don't really know what they do!

headline: IFS
pros:
- Amazing resources
- Stress about firm budget very rarely impacts employees (versus smaller firms, who very tightly monitor expenses, travel, software investments, etc.) which really allows you to focus on giving your best
- Work perks abound, including health perks, gifts, and spot bonuses
- Though it is very hierarchal, depending on your group you can contribute ideas and have them move very quickly into reality
- Amazing work experience; you sink or swim, but if you're swimming, you're learning so much so quickly and really are enabled to be at the top of your field
- Cell phone paid for, which is wonderful with the expectation of periodic messages outside of hours...I don't think it's fair when other firms expect you to distribute your personal number and install a bunch of work-related apps on your personal phone
- If you can find time to take PTO, it's a lot easier to find support covering your projects than it is at smaller firms
- Colleagues are incredibly smart
- Good benefits and excellent holiday/leave policies
- Recently brought all of the member firms throughout all the countries together, operating as one PwC, which was long overdue
cons:
- Long hours, especially working with international teams
- Expectation is extremely high--perform not only at the top of your game, but find new ways to contribute with side projects and innovation ideas
- The new "Snapshot" reviews that replaced previous annual review papers is easier to navigate, but does not capture year-to-year growth between career reviews; you essentially start over every year arguing your value (as opposed to leaders being able to see 2+ years  of steady contribution and accolades)
- IFS (internal firm services) professionals are mostly second class citizens, and will never have the earning power or the opportunities of a client-facing professional
- Tendency is to reward through cash or gift card spot bonuses, instead of upping salary--which never keeps anyone happy for long
- Limited advancement opportunities with some groups in IFS
- Work environment is better than most, but still favors men and has a persistent boys' club atmosphere at times
- Annual reviews are frustratingly not transparent; you have no place at the table to discuss your case if you're hoping for a raise or advancement--results are just told to you after the fact
- Like all of the Big 4 and most big business, it's a very political environment

headline: It's worth it only if you're too desperate
pros:
If you're too desperate to find a job you can always go to McDonalds, they rarely reject applications. 
You learn how to communicate with people whom you would never meet or speak to outside McDonalds. 
The job at McDonalds makes you motivated to study harder and find a better job one day, especially after you meet your colleages and realize that most of them have no dreams or future plans.
cons:
For full-time crew members: Often you have this 4-5 hours period with so many people outside. During this period you have absolutely no time to have a rest, take a breath or even drink water. You don't have time to go to the toilet either, but you don't actually need it because even if you succeed to drink something then the heat in the kitchen and the constant rushing will instantly evaporate it in the form of sweat.
They may put you on the cashier's desk on your very first day and very first hour and don't feel like explaining to you how does it work and where all the stuff are.
Customers treat you like a trash just because you work there and they assume that you're not able to accomplish anything else in your life. 
You get burned on both the grill and the toaster every time you have to do something fast (so every day). It's painfull and it recovers slowly. My whole right hand is in scars... for only two weeks working in the kitchen. 
 Minimum wage and slavery. Germany: 8.51 euro per working hour. Two cheeseburgers cost 4 euro. You work about 30 minutes for two cheeseburges, but for that time you make about 30 of them, as well as 30 hamburgers and probably 4 bigmacs/tasty bacon/whatever...

headline: It's not one company; it's a million small companies all with different cultures
pros: Salary was decent; work from home was nice.  My immediate leader was fantastic and some of my colleagues were outstanding.  I had a solid team that I grew myself.  Internal collaboration tools were good, but prob should have been better at an org that size.  I had a great career oppty, provided by my direct leader.
cons: HR and talent management in general was just awful like something from the dark ages in terms of how they managed top talent.  Leadership above my direct leader was a hodge podge of backstabbing and political games, with a prison-like feel where you shank someone before they have a chance to shank you.  Far and away, the most unprofessional behavior I've ever seen in my 20+ year career came from senior leaders with GVP and SVP titles.  Most good people and good leaders led strong teams in spite of senior leadership not because of it.  I guess if you are far enough down you don't see it, but at a certain level it's just power games instead of doing what's right.  It feels like the company succeeds via sheer momentum and scale.

headline: Dingwall DotCom has huge turnover ... for a reason.
pros: The actual work is great. Drive The Highlands, talk to people, pat their dogs, deliver their shopping.
cons:
The junior management is painful, arbitrary and capricious. health and safety is a joke. I've been told to drive a truck in winter conditions with an illegally low-tread tyre, because it was the last running vehicle in the fleet, and to book a tyre change when I got back. I've been told to take steps for H&S (quite rightly), but when the manager was pressed to do the same thing when he was driving, he couldn't be bothered. But three weeks later, he chewed me out for not doing it (the truck he saw wasn't mine, I had done it to mine). The actual job is great, dealing with Tesco sucks.

While I was working there, they ditched the employee bonus scheme, and gave us a pennies per hour pay rise instead, which left me about £200/year worse off. But the board kept their bonuses flowing. This is typical of the attitude to junior employees that I experienced from most, but not all managers.

headline: Very interesting project work with a very large, bureaucratic company
pros: Great name recognition; IBM is a very well respected brand across the board. As a result, you'll get exposure to client work with top players across various industries.
cons: For those looking to do pure strategy consulting work, this is the wrong firm (no matter what the recruiters tell you). There's so many organizational changes it's hard to keep up. And the company is so big, you can feel "lost", and moves to other opportunities are rare and complicated. It's also VERY hierarchical and bureaucratic; I know of several who had their hands slapped for having the nerve to ask a question of a high level manager or partner (exact words were "if you knew what their position is, you'd know not to bother them with a question about our little team". That says a lot right there. Also, in a case of irony, the technology supplied for IBMers is subpar, and the movement of information throughout the company is slow and archaic.

headline: Worst employer on the planet
pros: Might help you get another job
cons: google 'Oracle' for cons - a very unhealthy workplace - customers despise Oracle business practices, and staff take the heat, not upper managment

headline: Amazing company with ample flexibility, work-life balance and opportunities to learn
pros:
There are different groups within IBM with slightly different work environments/opportunities, however, all governed by the same company policies. For example, if you work for GBS, you may not get a lot of learning opportunities or flexibility in your work timings given the fact that its a Services division and you cater directly to customers and most of the things are governed by their own compliance policies like having to mandatorily work from the office due to the secure nature of the project, etc.

This review is for the IBM Software Labs.

1. Great learning opportunities as you have DevOps, Watson and latest cloud tech to work on.
2. You have all the available tools for self-learning and full admin access on your company laptop to install any tool approved by the company and be innovative.
3. There is a lot of flexibility in the timings which of-course depends on your manager and your work.
4. Leaves are not an issue. You have unlimited sick and casual leaves subject to approval and responsible use.
5. You get a MAC Pro.
6. If you have worked long enough and have consistent good ratings, you have project managers willing to take you in their project even though you may not be new to the technology. They have faith on you that you will pick up soon.
7. If you are really smart, you can make really good incentives by filing patents and its encouraged. Anyone can file patent, even if you are a fresher.
8. The only company that doesn't count the in-time and out-time. They trust their employee. Again this is subject to your manager.

With all that said, there can ofcourse be exceptions to the above like every other company. I have seen the worst and the best in this company and if you have a little patience with this company and get yourself in the right project with the right manager, you are good.

Remember, you never leave a company, you leave your manager.
cons:
1. IBM is still lacking in the compensation department. The payouts are not very competitive as compared to other product companies. For services, it may be at par.
2. Recently, there has been an effort on co-locating the employees and talks of removing 'work from home' policies which is really not required. This actually inconvenience the employees and reduces productivity and has been one of the perks of working in IBM which encourages employees to invest more time in the work.

headline: Good
pros:
The benefits are pretty good. Provides health insurance and stock purchase at a discount.
Work life balance is decent, but largely depending on manager.
A lot of day offs provided per year, even for new employees.
Training is pretty good. A lot of classes offered both technical and non technical.
Employee engagement is good, senior management is trying its best to listen to the low level employees and hear them out.
Fellow employees are pretty friendly and easy to get along with. There is not much cut throat competition.
HSBC offers special banking benefits to employees.
cons:
Promotions is biased. It is based on who brown noses the best and favoritism rather than on merit.
A lot of the managers do not know anything about what they are managing thus making a big joke of everything and leaving everything for the analysts to figure out.
Some managers are strict about taking day offs. Thus negating the purpose of having a lot of day offs. 
Cafeteria food is overpriced and inedible. Work location is in the middle of nowhere - long commute times.

headline: Dehumanizing
pros: Some of the people with whom I worked were pros for this organization - some of my peers, the technical line staff, and occasionally an executive who understands the balance of delivering well with ensuring overdelivery is avoided.  Executives take the manager's side on most manager-employee disputes.
cons: They offer very poor compensation vs. the market, and offer no consideration of work-life balance.  People at sub-executive levels literally live in fear of "resource actions" that are executed annually to move more resources offshore for a (currently) favorable price model.  Repositioning the truth to the customer to reflect internal changes in policy or strategy is commonplace.

headline: Marriott: Nice Benefits
pros:
At Marriott we embrace a unique code of service we call “spirit to serve”. We believe it’s essential that each of us do our part to make a difference in the lives of others, whether it’s our fellow associates, customers, business partners or neighbors.

Marriott offers a competitive compensation and benefits package that you’d expect from an industry leader and we provide the programs and resources that help our associates achieve a true sense of satisfaction – on and off the job.
 
In keeping with our associate-centered culture, Marriott’s benefits package includes:

   1. Medical, dental, life & disability insurance
   2. 401(k) retirement savings plan
   3. Continuing education/tuition reimbursement
   4. Ongoing training and career development programs
   5. Work/family programs and services
   6. Discounts on hotel rooms, food & beverage
cons: Dealing with annoying,upset, and stuck-up customers.

headline: Apple's greateast facade
pros: A refreshingly collaborative environment that lends itself to personal growth and development. There is a stringent hiring process, but it ultimately results in the organization sourcing candidates that are like-minded, empathetic, and forming connections is generally pretty easy.
cons: Growth opportunities are limited and ultimately a byproduct of favoritism rather than any real sense of objectivity and what is sensible for the team. Within the last month, the interview process has been moderately altered and offers more of a sense of objectivity, but is ultimately farcical. Initiatives at the retail level ultimately revolve around meeting the demand of unreliable performance metrics and wildly varying company directives. The organization also lays claim to compassion and direct action toward protecting human rights without recognition to its own transgressions against humanity, utilizing slave / internment labor to fulfill manufacturing in China, compliance with initiatives which stand directly against any modicum of humanity. Between the stockpile of cash reserves, the year over year growth in valuation and earnings, one would think that they would pay their employees more fairly, but that's also tossed to the wayside. There is not any shred of real accountability or integrity within the confines of this place, and anyone who states otherwise is participating in and complicit with the facade.

headline: [Luton head office] Could be great...already is if you get in “the club”
pros:
Nice office with generally good facilities.

Friendly colleagues.

Finally seem to be getting more digital, albeit well behind the curve.
cons:
No chance of progression unless you brown-nose your way into “the club”...i.e. get chummy with the directors.

Work-life balance is a double-edged sword. Yes you can have one...but unless your “presence” is noted in the office (read as chained to desk at all hours, forget seeing your spouse and kids), you forego any chance of progression. It all seems to be about how long you’re in the office, not the quality of what you deliver, the impact you make or how efficient you are.

Luton location is a nightmare for hiring specialist roles, double-whammied by poor rates of pay.

Pace of change is laughable, particularly with anything involving IT...and if you want something signed off, be prepared for 1,000 hours of meetings and navigating your way through the 9 circles of hell.

headline: Balfour Beatty Ideal Placement Year Company
pros:
Great training initatives, good close knit team, support from staff on and off site is great.

During placement year I was really allowed to progress, by the end of the placement I was undertaking a number of big (for placement year) responsibilities. I was intergrated fully into the site team and welcomed from the very begining.

The HR & training teams allowed me to attend serveral training courses I thought would be left until becoming a full time employee, but from earliy on they were investing in my development.
- week long Site Surveying Course, 4 star hotel paid for, food & travel expenses
- during placement completed level 3 NVQ allowing progression to Gold CSCS
- CSCS test and card paid and organised by Balfour Beatty

All work travel expenses paid, which is a huge help when working in london, travel card £300+ a month!!

Good social scene and atmosphere between all areas of the company I came into contact with.

Most importantly I was able to learn a great, great deal during my placement year from the experienced people I was able to work with. Built hugely on the theoretical knowledge from university and lots of opportunities to put it into practice. Whilst working on the project I was considered a full member of the site team, not as 'the uni student' to be kept to simple tasks. I was given as much work as  could handle and able to work using my own initative regularily (not constantly checked and monitored) which gave me a great feeling of trust.

Whilst there I had great feed back from the site team, project office team, and the project director on my progress.

It was a great working year and I have recently been offered a graduate position once completing my degree, which I accepted straight away. If you have the opportunity to carry out a placement with Balfour Beatty I would strongly accept it, not just on site though. Through the friends I met at the company also on placements based off site they feel the same way.
cons:
- Due to the nature of the job you may need to work additional hours without overtime, but the salary you recieve takes this into account and any person in a managment position on site needs to accept this.
- You may get moved about as projects are completed or to where you are needed most, but I like this aspect of the job.

headline: Run
pros: Worked with some nice colleagues.
cons:
Everything else. 

- Growth through acquisition/diversification strategy is not working. The businesses are not integrated, not complimentary and don't collaborate at all.
- Company is run by finance. The business only focuses on the next earning call and its appearance to the market (leading to frequent rounds of firing before reporting results). 
- The company has all of the worst hack aspects of a search firm ingrained into the culture (flying by the seat of pants, no real expertise, searches actually run by kids out of college while Partners sit back and watch the dollars roll in).  
- No interest in wellbeing/development/happiness of employees. 
- Very backward looking, old school (in the worst sense) mentality. Most Partners are wannabe country club types.  
- No pay rise. Ever. 
- Terrible bonus (company claims poverty every bonus cycle but appears to have saved a ton of cash).
- Terrible benefits (the healthcare package is terrible) 
- You will work most evenings and weekends as you will have more searches to execute than is possible. 
-Don't even think about taking a vacation (unless you are a Partner). 
- Most of your colleagues will rotate out of the business on a regular basis.

headline: IT Division Very Backward
pros:
Staff generally friendly
Many staff are passionate about cars which is great if you're also into that
cons:
IT division is very backward. The issues stem from the senior and middle management. Most make huge efforts to avoid taking decisions and responsibility. A few are very keen but end up loaded with so much pressure that they can only focus on immediate priorities, so overall there is very little planning for the future and very little innovation, it's all firefighting.

Too many of the management are not from an IT background at all - JLR prefer to recruit internally so they take people from mechnical engineering, management or even production line backgrounds.

Huge reliance on contractors because of the lack of specialist IT skills. Some are great but others do very little work and stay for years on great pay.

Lots of red tape - the worst I have seen. The processes are rigid but often not best practice.

Huge use of offshore Tata Group consultancy for development. Individually some developers are great, but many are grads who are trained to standards 10 years behind best practice. Collectively it is poorly managed. Timescales are rarely met and communication is poor, but they are not held accountable as they will always be used next time rather than going externally.

Because of the above issues, many projects go around for years, at great expense but never getting anywhere. By the time they come around again, the original people have left and everything is repeated. Factory staff rightly have huge distrust of IT for this reason, and work around the IT processes, leading to further problems and difficultly engaging.

headline: Great for career but no work-life balance
pros: The skills you learn at Big 4 are invaluable for your career whether you stay at Big 4 or leave for industry. In 4 years, I was managing a large team of staff and seniors for one of the largest private clients in our division. Some of those skills include working with difficult clients and upper management, recruiting new interns/staff, performing accounting research on complex issues, time management, managing interns/staff/other seniors, and so much more.
cons: Absolutely no work-life balance. You are told every year that the next busy season will be better. My experience was the hours actually got worse every year (avg. around 80 hours per week during busy season and about 60 hours per week the rest of the year) and our busy season was extended to 5 months out of the year.

headline: Incredible growth opportunities across many dimensions but hampered by a inward looking culture
pros: Been in the firm for awhile now and it offers a great environment to grow in any dimension you are passionate about as long as you drive your career yourself and avoid doing just what comes. A sales driven culture that demands top notch execution, if you are not passionate about selling or fail at execution you are dead in the water here. The leadership team is great at driving the business forward and has continued to do a great job driving the firm forward.
cons: It's a very exclusive culture where if your not one of them, your pretty much going to reach a ceiling quick. The firm does a great job running a sales and execution business but does a horrible job at everything else. Luckily, the partners and the engine they built are so good that the business continues to thrive just by closing big deals and executing on them successfully. They are trying hard to innovate and nurture a different culture they sense is coming but ultimately they don't get it. All innovation is top down driven, needs to look and feel the same as what the partnership has been comfortable doing for the last 10-20 years which filters out 80% of what innovation is about. The culture is still all network based (who you know and help is your currency) and if you look, speak and think differently you will stand out as an outcast despite how successful you may be. It's a partnership model that wants to build more of the same partners not more of something different and potentially better.

headline: Toxic, dominated by aggressive , bullying male behaviour
pros:
Some great team members especially in SAP consultancy team.  
Good salary
large organization if you wished to move around
cons:
Targets are irrelevant to the market potential and needs.
 So many re-structuring due to company buyouts, so one day you have a sales bag and the next day it has changed so as your target. This breaths bullying mechanism within the organization so the middle management can achieve their targets. I was bullied by two managers as I stood my ground for bringing value to customers rather than just closing a deal, they bullied me to the point that I was forced to resign, even though I met the target numbers by 80%. Both of the manager's intentions were to cut cost so they can hire in another region as I had a healthy pipeline built and inside sales could close the deals.  They even got promotion from Australia to APAC. 
This experience brought major depression to me and eventually I had my first Lupus attack. I will never forget how these managers behaved, HR and others knew about it and no one did anything. Terrible culture and I hope karma catch the guys on top, as this should never happen to any females at work.

location: Salford, North West England, England, England
headline: Junior Software Engineer at the BBC
pros:
- Any cynicism you might have aside, the company and most colleagues really care about the mission and being a force for good. While the results may vary, the effort seems to really be there.

- Work Life balance is excellent in all the teams I've worked in/got to know, and most people I've meet seems content. The only rare days I left late was due to me being engrossed by a piece of work, and never due to a looming deadline.

- There are a lot of initiative on environment preservation, well being and about underrepresented group,  and on trying to make the right thing.

- Benefits like pension and medical are good, but don't expect many standard tech companies 'freeebies'. (we're a public company after all, can't splurge that taxpayer money on anything but the most basic instant coffee!)

- The company is trying hard to improve its work methods by pushing agile and modern development techniques/stacks.

- Canteen in Salford might not be the cheapest but I'll forever miss those Pork Burritos.

All in all, it a positive experience where I learned a lot and met people I loved to work with every day. Would probably have stayed longer if progression was faster and extra effort rewarded, and if the team were given more freedom in the tech choices
cons:
- Progression and pay: Last year all progression and pay reviews for Design+Engineering were frozen, with various (empty) promises of something better coming alongside "soon". This, alongside salary band that are nothing to write home about, means that you have to negotiate yourself a good Salary when you join because it won't change by much for a long time. While your colleague might recognise and cherish your hard work and achievements, that won't speed up the pace of your career.

- A lot of internal, baroque tooling and framework being used, leading to very poor engineer experience and lot of extremely domain-specific knowledge and expertise which makes it hard to on-board new people, and has little value outside the BBC.

- Red tape. Red tape everywhere: Too many 'heads of something', 'senior manager of something else'. Company tree is not that deep, but sure has lots of branches and lots of Stakeholder to approve your work.

- The culture still feels very TV (and Radio, maybe) first, with Digital just being that "also there" thing.

- Very little/no giving back to open source :(

headline: Tough place to advance your career
pros: Good benefits, respected company, good people, competitive pay.  As a sales person IBM has name recognition with customers, which helps get your foot in the door.  Was a better place to work when I started a few years back than it is now.
cons:
Tough to advance, unclear career paths, not enough focus on career development, hardly ever give raises, constant change in strategy - never stick with one strategy long enough to gauge its success, lots of bureaucracy (too many systems and tools, too much reporting required), not great at rewarding/recognizing success, risk/fear of layoffs.  

Pay plans are convoluted to the point where no one really understands exactly how they get paid.  Every year I worked there they changed the pay plan to pay us less and very few folks got raises (and those who did said the raises were a joke).   They have been cutting back recognition programs the last couple of years so high performance isn't really rewarded anymore.  Job is always at risk to be eliminated - lots of layoffs in inside sales the last few years.

headline: Perfect recipe for success - intellectual challenges, support and fun!
pros:
Bain’s apprenticeship model means that I have been working with the very best in the business from Day 1.  Each day, I am lucky to learn from colleagues across many different disciplines and tenure levels – from analyst right through to partner. The supportive culture and mentoring at Bain has honestly exceeded my expectations, and I know that I have a really strong support network within the business. I’ve become a great consultant because of the investment that my colleagues have made in me. 
During my time at Bain Australia, I’ve worked on clients across many different industries, and focussed on solving many different problems. The one thing that has remained constant through all cases has been Bain’s absolute commitment to achieving results. Every day, we work to help our clients achieve new levels of success – I feel like part of the client teams during our cases, and our client’s successes are our own. It’s the most collaborative atmosphere I’ve ever experienced. 
Bain Australia is a great place to start your career – a perfect mix of challenging work with the right support systems in place, great clients who are striving to achieve more with their businesses and an incredible culture. The people at Bain are exceptional – intelligent, ambitious and always up for fun. I feel extremely lucky to call myself a Bainee!
cons: We do work hard to achieve great client results, but the business acknowledges this and puts a lot of effort into creating a sustainable work/life balance. As a result, we're lucky at Bain Australia to have abolished 'face-time' culture often expected in professional services firms.

headline: Learn a lot, great exit opportunities, but terrible work-life balance.
pros:
The below is related to Core Assurance:
- Bonus for getting CPA license: $6,000 + all expenses incurred related to obtaining CPA +5,000 = roughly $11,000 of extra comp not included in salary figure above.
- Great culture around pushing yourself to learn more and get out of your comfort zone
-Major emphasis on learning digital skills (i.e., Alteryx, UiPath, PowerBI) and they provide all the resources/time to do so
-Surrounded by very dedicated, driven, talented people 
- In my experience, I have at least one recruiter a week reach out about a job opportunity post big-4. More often than not, I receive multiple job opportunities via LinkedIn every week
cons: -Despite what the recruiters say, this is a very intense and time-intensive job. Definitely not 9-5 (but who honestly thought Big-4 audit was?) Busy season is the most intense experience I've ever had, and probably ever will have. But on the flip side, that's why you sign up - to have those crazy experiences with very dedicated, driven individuals who are all looking to better themselves. Moral of the story, if your not looking to hustle, this job is definitely not for you.

headline: It is OK but not the great place it used to be.
pros: Working in IBM development you have access to the latest technical advancements.  It is not difficult to find an area of interest within the product development and the current environment of "do more with less and more quickly" does allow engineers to expand their horizons by taking on responsibilities in areas they have not previously had an opportunity to explore.
cons: Schedules and product requirements are constantly changing and by the time they figure out what they want, the engineers are forced to scramble in order to make extremely aggressive deadlines.  Layoffs and reorgs have left most teams with less resource than they need to do their jobs.  The rating system is demotivating since people who work very hard are likely to get the same rating as those doing little work.

headline: NOT a good company to work for.
pros: On the whole, my colleagues are great. They have your back; will jump in to help out and the team spirit is fantastic. Pay is reasonable in comparison to private sector ONLY; DWP employees are the lowest paid throughout the civil service. Leave and flexi leave are good, if they can be taken, which is rare. I only work part time hours now, but was full time for 14 years. (Health grounds, work related stress).
cons: Management. Poor communication and too many instances where the ‘customer is always right’ when they are clearly far from it. I was a witness to an incident between a member of staff and a customer, and Management took the side of the customer. My colleague got a disciplinary for sticking up for herself. Zero tolerance doesn’t exist.  Progression is encouraged, but applications have to be agreed by your Line Manager and when you request it you are told ‘you’re business critical’ so no, you are not allowed to further yourself. Staff will lose morale quickly. If you have had work related health issues then be prepared for little backup from managers, a disregard of OHS advice and the threat of termination of employment (no longer sustainable to business needs; even if it is work related). If you don’t meet the ‘there are no targets anymore’ targets it does get mentioned. To anyone thinking of working for this company; read all the reviews from customer facing staff (Work Coaches, primarily) for the real picture. Some older staff are institutionalised and happily shrug off work where possible. The work/life balance advertised is good, unless you are looking for leave during school holidays.  The continual add ons to our time are becoming ridiculous. There are only so many hours in the day to interview.

headline: This is not your father's IBM, and that's too bad.........
pros: IBM used to be a great place to work. They have big company benefits and name recognition which bolster your resume and IBM is highly regarded in the industry. One of the biggest benefits to working for IBM is the ability to work from a home office, which saves you time and money by removing the commute from your daily routine, although IBM does get that commute time back from you in extra hours worked. Another great advantage to working for IBM is exposure to insiders at Fortune 500 companies that may help you in your job search once you're thoroughly disgusted with IBM.
cons:
IBM no longer has respect for the individual. Employees are treated as commodities. Benefits have eroded and IBM no longer pays market for their skills. Some items that are touted as benefits (such as tuition reimbursement) are not available for the employee population at large. IBM used to have a pretty good bonus program (variable pay) but the percentages have tumbled even as the stock has risen to a 7 year high. IBM touts itself as a company that supports work-life balance, but the truth of the matter is that they've laid off so many people that the folks that are left (that haven't been reclassified as non-exempt workers) are forced to work more hours to get the same job done. Also, IBM lags other companies in their own leveraging of technology. My advice: if you have a comparable offer elsewhere, take it. If you work for IBM in the US and haven't already been offshored, it's just a matter of time. 

IBM is so process-heavy that it can't get out of it's own way. People in IBM use the "process" to avoid doing the right thing for the customer.  Way too much red tape for my taste and the customer always takes a back seat to whatever IBM's pet program is at the time.

headline: Stunningly Bad Management
pros: One of a few companies still running an old-style defined benefit pension plan.  They also have a 401k plan.   Not much else.
cons:
Bank of New York is the most bureaucratic company that I have ever seen.  Often, tasks are divided up among so many organizations that no one has ownership of any single initiative or project, so when it fails or fails to be completed, no one is responsible.

The organization is filled with many groups with overlapping responsibilities.  While the bank thinks that it is becoming lean and mean, it is not, as these groups, all with their own agendas, cancel each other out and make moving any initiative forward a morass.  

Management is tentative and uncertain on how to make changes.  It is the most incompetent management, I have ever seen within the 14-15 companies that I have worked for wqithin my career.         

There is almost no concern for quality of any product or service produced.  Management does not engage with line employees and does its best to ignore problems which affect quality and output of work.  There is no meaningful incentive for employees to work hard or be effective.  Most employees are therefore not motivated and take as many opportunities as possible to move the problem "off their desk" without fixing it.

headline: Fantastic Approach Towards Consulting
pros:
APT is a compelling alternative to traditional consulting (MBB), and exposes its consultants to advanced statistical concepts and data manipulation skills.  Quality and range of exit opportunities are pretty comparable to MBB, albeit you won't have the name recognition.  If you see yourself leaning more towards a career in the technology industry (PM, data scientist), this place will prepare you far better than traditional consulting.  

APT has a phenomenal business outlook.  When I joined, the company was growing 25% YoY, and still is today.  In fact, some of our biggest problems involve having too many things to do for its consultants.

The people here are exceptional, and are very open to giving feedback, should you ask for it.  

The company is not yet a household name within consulting, but has some level of name recognition amongst recruiters, consultants, clients, and classmates.  Despite this, APT has excellent business school placements - this year, we have 2 people in our SF office (~45 people) alone going to HBS.  In the DC office, I know of several more who are going to Stanford GSB.  

There is a wide variety of tasks that business consultants are exposed to, including data manipulation, analysis, presentation, and client relationship building.  We work with a wide number of industries, spanning traditional retail, CPG, pharmaceuticals, entertainment, technology, restaurants, hotels, finance, etc.

The work life balance is generally good, and this is bolstered by a culture of traveling only when necessary.  Standing desks, monitors, keyboards, noise cancelling headphones, and more are all provided to consultants to help them be more productive.  

There is room for international travel, and transfers across roles (e.g. consulting to marketing to product management) or regions (SF to DC to Australia to Taipei) still occur every year.
cons:
APT staffs its consultants across a number of clients.  Most consultants here are on at least 5 clients, which means that the work can be very spiky.  
	
	Compensation is the best in the consulting industry for the entry level, but is quickly outpaced around 2-3 years in.  This growth rate will be irrelevant if you only plan on staying 2 years or less.  
	
	Due to lots of turnover across consulting clients, consultants need to constantly retrain new non-technical employees in the complicated analytics that our software performs.  Helping clients figure out which buttons to click is a tremendous exercise in frustration.  The work can quickly become repetitive, but that is also due to how effective the software is at mapping a diverse set of problems down to the same problem - test vs. control scientific experimental design and analysis.
	
	There is a huge amount of turnover in the SF office, which leads to consultants often being asked to fix things that are poorly documented, without any original context.

cons: Be really careful about checking what the recruiters tell you because it’s not true at all.  They get you in and then you start finding out the truth that the centers are not anything like the rest of the company, basically it’s like a call center with a bunch of people who are competing for work. The benefits in the centers are pretty minimal and they offer NO flexibility even though you’re told the company is one of the best employers. If you work in the centers you’re considered cheaper labor and get paid way less than other employees. That’s good for the company and clients but sad for the people who were excited to work for them.

headline: Hilton Review
pros: Hilton afford all the necessary conditions to bring out the best in each one. I was lucky to complete interesting trainings which help me improve my skills especially in sales. They also encourage and recognize team members's efforts and offer good opportunities for the career development.

headline: Excellent progression opportunites within a supprotive company.
pros:
Capita are excellent at recognising and prompting talent from within, which has meant I have had many opportunities to progress skills and work in areas that I would not have had chance to work in otherwise. 
The career pathways within the area of the business I work are only getting clearer as Capita are investing in their people. There has been a lot of support in each post I have worked and I feel there is an open door policy to the senior management team which encourages every person within the business to gain as much experience as they want to.
cons: Many of the progression opportunities are based in Birmingham, which I have not found to be an issue however colleagues who live further away have found this a block to their career options.

headline: Project/Program Management
pros: Flexible work hours to start, but working at home , you have tendency to overwork with long hours , evenings and weekends.
cons: Cloud, Watson, and new Logo's not making quota. Layoffs every quarter, losing experienced talent, and morale very low.  Behind the curve of competitors and losing traction competing with winning new business. End of working long hours in evening and over weekend. Not able to take vacation yearly due layoffs every quarter and loss of many skilled peers, and end up working until very end of year. Have to get management approval yearly to carry over vacation, if you don't use it , you lose it.

headline: Generally Good Company To Work For
pros: Worked within motor claims. Generally Aviva is a good company to work for as they have financial benefits such as Pension, Shares, Holiday packages & an annual bonus. Within the insurance industry they are one of the market leaders having worked for other insurers. They are trying to run using a system thinking principles which in theory works but managers are likely to priortise taking inbound calls over existing work sometimes to the detriment of other work.
cons:
If you are not prepared the 'brown nose' the right management then you are not likely to exceed in the company.
The company regularly makes cuts and redundancies, to suit annual savings for the current CEO, then will go on the employ further staff the following year.

headline: Management is terrible
pros: Absolutely nothing, hours suck, most coworkers had very bad temperaments
cons: Management is absolutely terrible, obvious favoritism, hitting on employees, throwing temper tantrums and leaving the store for hours on end. Second day on the job I was left in the store to manage cashier and all the orders during lunch rush. They had me do all the heavy lifting and I am a scrawny female, even though there was clearly more capable workers at the time. Manager would come up to me while I’m making pizzas during lunch rush to show me cat videos... very unprofessional work environment and the manager was a huge baby.

cons: No job security ever. The intent of the company is to treat full-time people like contractors. Politics growing as the same senior people get the opportunities, so you are in or you are out. Benefits decreasing. No longer good for families. Constant layoffs that never seem to effect the top layer. Stopping employees from taking vacation by giving them so much work that its impossible. Forget any opportunity if you stay too long. Silicon Valley hours and expectations without the shared equity.

headline: Depends on your team

Ample time off, a sincere effort to promote work/life balance stems from the top down (many people work from home), and supportive staff.  Bureaucratic systems, although a pain to deal with, support the effective and relatively smooth running of the organization.  Many training opportunities.
cons: Your experience is wholly dependent upon which group you are in.  It can be difficult to change groups and movement within the organization is often based on who you know.

headline: Great opportunities, poor people focus
pros: JPMC is a historically impressive company and a name everyone recognizes. There are enormous opportunities for growth and development within the company. It is a great place to start a career and with enough work you truly can make whatever you want of it once you're in. The face pace can be exciting and we have some excellent leaders within top levels of the company.
cons: The company places little to no focus on valuing its employees, most are just seen as replaceable pegs in holes. Work life balance is something that senior leaders love to talk about but is rarely actually supported. It's all about getting to the top and being the best, running over whoever you need to in the process.

headline: Loved It

headline: Great in theory, poor in execution
pros:
Flexible working times due to shift work
Great people to work with

cons:
Poor management
Terms and conditions on contract 
Poor communication throughout departments

headline: Stay away
pros:
- world is your oyster attitude, which allowed some progressive initiatives like community service

- some genuinely nice people who are willing to share their experiences and network with you

- remote work possible if on the right team
cons:
For a top HR firm, they ironically can’t practice what they preach.

A truly horrible place to work. Good ol’ boy culture, and also a “No-culture culture”. Everyone works so hard that there is no incentive to really connect with peers. 

-Lack of diversity with old men who feel like they can disrespect you by being exceptionally rude or by making lewd comments.  Literally had a partner start to hit on me and then his admin put him in check. A couple older partners who are dated and feel that they can be a**holes to their admin and lower staff because of tenure and how much money they bring in. 

-No work-life balance (was literally told I shouldn’t be saying “no” to any work even though I was over capacity). A principal I spoke to essentially said that the only way for me to progress was to not have any boundaries with work. It was only after 12+ years of really hard work (like constant nights and weekends) in the business did they finally respect this person’s request to set boundaries so they could spend time with family.

- no raises; lack of communication about raises and how to get a raise (most likely bc they didn’t do that)
- no career development discussions unless initiated by yourself
- no mentorship in place unless you ask someone specifically
- no regular feedback of performance
- siloed work environment 
- leadership and partners are not invested in your growth or you as a person- only the work you can produce

Research work SUCKS. I was told there would be more variety in this particular role but that is simply not the truth. The majority of your work (like 90-95%) is using various databases like LinkedIn and Zoom to find candidates and then spending hours plugging them into the KF database and updating candidate profiles. Barely interact with candidates and definitely next to no interaction with clients. Not intellectually challenging or stimulating.  Only occasionally did I get to help create deliverables.

headline: great place to work.

headline: Working in this role is equivalent to being tortured
pros: Only pro was my co workers.
cons:
Where do I begin? If you like to be micromanaged, insulted, abused, verbally tormented, disrespected, embarrassed, belittled, yelled at, and felt like you are dumber than a door knob than this place is perfect for you! 
My manager is a walking tyrant that feeds her ego and inability to be a human being by making employees feel like they are of below intelligence level. I have worked here for not even a year and I feel like I’ve been held in prison for years. I’ve been accused of stealing an office plant that weighs more than I do, as well as an old office chair. Thinking of working overtime? Just don’t. You will be scorned for wanting to put more hours in the office. Discrimination and racism isn’t even the start of some of the “perks” you can find at Cushman and Wakefield, weight and physical appearance are targeted to. Ripped your pantyhose? Too bad. You will have to walk around the office looking like a harlot because “running errands should be done only on your personal time”. I hated working for the person I did so much, that sometimes I would secretly wish that she would get into an accident on the way to work and be unable to ever come back to work.

headline: Very good place to work in if your career path is recruitment or HR
pros: Have the chance to work with top tier world leaders and learn from their work methodology and way of thinking. Some consultants (esp. the younger ones) are high-caliber profiles but still very open-minded when communicating with you. Constantly updated with how the industry is evolving.
cons: In the end, it is a corporate and you will need to act in a way that is obedient or in favor of the boss. Local offices can be mono-culture. No space for creativity or business sassiness because there is no KPI. Very (or sometimes, solely) focused on blue-chip profiles, this reflects on both their internal candidate selection as well as candidate selection for clients, where everyone comes from the top universities or McKinsey (they really love McKinsey). At least in my office, anyone who has an alternative view/thinking can feel tongue-tied. As an example, some of the consultants still believe the core quality that every corporate is looking for can be measured by a simple IQ test.

headline: Business Account Manager

headline: Overall, a positive experience over 14 years with the company
pros: One of the best things about MSFT has always been the ability to take on very different roles and to work across any number of businesses. Benefits of course of first rate.
cons: While the recently made modifications to address issues, I have seen and personally experiences the oddities created by the MSFT's curve-based, stack-rank performance review system. cons:
Always under pressure to meet kpi targets which were often changed to meet a higher expectations once met.
Deliveries were rarely organized upon arrival and often too much stock was sent in for the size of the store which meant constant layout changes which was time consuming and put pressure on staff members. 
Promotion changes as well as price adjustments were often changed  last minute again putting pressure on staff and management in store to complete in time.
Hourly rate was low for job title and responsibilities and no chance or opportunity to develop.
Area managers were often disorganised and changed often which made it hard to resolve problems with individual stores.

Wealth Management is a wonderful place to work and the environment has been nothing other than friendly and helpful.  I would recommend spending as much time possible getting a feel for the work environment at your location during any interview.

headline: It's like a nursery, you can grow rapidly, but only for a few it's a long-term job.
pros:
You work mostly with smart and intelligent colleagues and managers, from whom you can learn. 

The variety in industries and clients that you may attend to are an enormous booster for your working experience. Also good for CV building and connecting with companies to plan your eventual leave.

Initially, its very hard work, but immensely challenging and rewarding. 

Decent benefits.
cons:
Work-life balance is extremely poor. Long hours and little time off. However, this is wide-spread in BIG-4 and most other accounting/tax/financial services firms.

Highly hierarchical organization. It's the Deloitte way, and challenging that is frequently frowned upon.

As you rise through the ranks, the exiting parts of executing and managing teams gives way to network building and sales activities. If this is not your strong-suit or not what you signed up for, the only way is out. 

Starter salaries are low and gradually rise to average. However, this highly depend on the service line you work in. Some pay abysmally, some have decent pay. Again, this is the business model of these type of firms, and not just at Deloitte. You are the product, you are the asset, and pricing is constantly under enormous pressure. Deloitte Mexico prefers to attend a large volume at lower cost, than having a quality first approach. This is not a strategical error at all, but it doesn't make for a great workplace.

cons: Outdated systems and outmoded ways of thinking. A lack of trust from senior management down to the individual employee in many cases. headline: Good place to start your career
pros: MyRyan will improve your quality of life and is a major competitive advantage over Ryan's industry competitors.  I've heard the ability to use MyRyan differs upon which team you are assigned, but it has helped me to improve my work quality greatly.  Brint Ryan the CEO is aggressive in expanding Ryan's market share, and he is intently willing to adopt creative suggestions from his employees.  My managers and the principal at my office location are excellent, I really lucked out.  Brint announced the 401(k)  will soon be improved to make it one of the best in the industry.
cons: I have one issue with Ryan, but it is a major one.  It is my experience that Ryan does not make cost of living adjustments depending on the market.  The base pay Ryan offers to tax consultants in my market is just not competitive.  Consultants based out of Dallas make more bonus pay because of oil and gas projects there, but my cost of living is almost twice what theirs is, not to mention the enormous disparity in purchasing power.  There has been about 80% turnover in tax consultants at my office in just the past two years.  Ryan's business model is excellent and Brint is honest when he says employees are his first priority, I just wish the firm showed more commitment to keeping talented people long-term who are just starting out.

headline: Deloitte: Where the best choose to leave.
pros: Deloitte is recognized as a reputable firm in the US. The "value proposition" for joining Deloitte is the opportunity to gain more experience per year than one would get in industry. That's a politically correct way to say that you'll work ridiculous hours.
cons:
The firm, under the banner of "One Deloitte", is remarkably divided and rife with internal competition among practice groups. If you find yourself working for the wrong partner or practice, you will not succeed. 
Deloitte promises to build your skills and industry expertise, but fails to execute. The Deloitte propaganda machine touts the firm's commitment to Mass Career Customization and instead delivers round after round of Mass Restructuring (p.c. for layoffs). 
The partnership admission process is nothing more than fraternity hazing ritual resulting in a top-heavy organization of underwhelming partners who fail to produce new business.

headline: Such a shame
pros: Hard to think of many at the time of leaving. I guess if you're a manager grade or above the package (rather than salary) is quite good. There are also some really good individuals who really do care.
cons: I worked at L&G for more than 5 years and when I joined it was a great place to work, quite paternalistic towards staff and there was a good work life balance. No more! They have cut numbers so far that people are so over worked and stressed that they are quite literally keeling over. Morale is rock bottom in the Kingswood office, which they are closing in 2018. There's also a huge technical debt and analysis paralysis is rife

headline: Manager can make or break your career
pros: Free health, dental and vision, 50% 401k match. Discount buying OS, office and Xbox games. Free bus pass in Seattle area.
cons: Poor management, either my way or highway. Hard working in MSFT won't lead you to reward. Super micro management, 1 on 1 with your manager every week, 4 x official reviews per year. Manager can make or break your career, manager can rank you at the bottom even you work hard. Ranking system still exist, believe me. Most of the managers been working there over 10 years, no idea how outside world work.

headline: Fun, great place to start a career.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great coaching/mentoring culture.   Excellent exposure to blue chip clients.  Will learn heaps and have opportunities to travel the world.  Young enthusiastic vibe and generally surrounded by like minded intelligent people.
cons: Can be very long hours and your experience will depend on the particular partners/directors and managers you work for.  For example, all the really good audit partners and directors left the office I was working with in somewhat of an exodus and the remaining ones didn't seem to care about the staff as much and appeared to be purely focused on partner incomes.

headline: Do not join this company
pros: Good pay with work life balance
cons:
Of lately, they are doing mass hiring, they plan to onboard at least 4k people as per their HRs, as per them it is due to they wanted to remove their dependency on contractors, I was offered a really good pay, but the truth is they don't have work. Most of the work is third grade, that they want to hide behind domain knowledge. You will be just doing production support in most projects..

Also before joining I heard of their hire and fire policy, well it has been one month here and I can say it is very much true.. each year they are short of budget, each year their policies change, sometime they want contractors , sometime they want permanent..If a projects does not have budget, they will just fire you, they won't even consider moving you to another department, even when there is opening out there..HR is almost non existant here.. Technology is very outdated, at the time of recruiting, they tell about clouds, mongoDbs, block chain, etc but all these are just there marketing strategies..I have also heard they have this habit of removing the whole team for cost cutting, like in my project there is no testing team, same thing they plan to do with L1 support team, they want these tasks to be handled by dev teams, so that they can get away with support teams as well and reduce cost..

Moreover employees are almost treated as cattle, literally resources, there are no benefits apart from your salary. 

In short, join only if you really don't have a choice

headline: Internal Accounta
pros:
-More like a data entry/administrative job if that's your thing. 
-Managers can be a hit or miss. Worked with one of the best manager who would always work with you and help you from the ground up while always being positive and friendly.
-Staff and seniors are all friendly and there to help.
cons:
-On the flip side, also worked with a toxic manger who would provide 0 guidance and scream, micromanage, and be completely unprofessional. Working with her was honestly the deal breaker for me.
-Work can feel unchallenging and even prehistoric at times (creating binders, folding paper, 99% of everything is done on pdf/excel, etc.).
-"Unlimited Time Off" here is a scam. Especially in this department as approval for doctor's visit, vacation time, and time off must be given weeks on advance and approved by all managers. 
-There's a reason why they give staff overtime...

I attended meetings where we were told the marching orders and future vision only to go back 6 months later and get a whole different set of direction.  You have to be "in the boys club" to get heard.  Frustrating, frustrating culture.  From the outside it looks friendly and open but once you go to work there you find it is anything but open.

headline: Good Place to work for few years
pros:
1. It is a well established bank.
2. Bank has spent lot of money and focus on infrastructure, automation and internal processes which work well like a well-oiled engine. Other banks haven't invested so much in infrastructure and automation processes for employees within company (this is from my personal experience of working in three banks here in Singapore).
3. Good opportunity to learn and grow if you have right people with you.
4. You get the flexible hours of working. I could work from home without any issues and my managers supported it. 
5. Company culture was good for learning and helped me a lot in learning new stuff.
6. Despite of not having a local manager in Singapore for 4 years, I never felt neglected and was well rewarded and taken care of my hard work by my managers in UK. (Previously, my local managers were horrible).
7. Company gives amazing redundancy package and is very generous in giving compensation. They are one of the best and will take care of you financially if your position is being made redundant. 
8. If your position would be made redundant, you could apply for positions in other departments (if available) or other low cost locations if you are willing to locate. 
9. If you are happy to relocate to low cost locations, you could apply to a higher position and get a promotion (provided you are in company for a while).
10. Per Singapore standards, they had ample leave plans (annual leaves, hospitalization, maternity and sabbatical).
11. Healthcare insurance plan was one of the best (includes dental and family).
12. Despite of your experience, if
- you are working hard and your manager recognizes it and fights for you.
Or 
- you have charmed right people enough (despite of not working much), you have better chances of promotion.
You will get promoted. People don't judge you from your experience, they evaluate based on your calibre and strength.
cons:
1. Due to flat hierarchy in designations, it was frustrating to move to next position. When their IT base in Singapore was huge, it was too much competition and less promotions. However, it became better post 2011/2012 once their IT strength was reduced. 
2. When they had Offshore development centre (ODC) concept in Singapore, they had horrible procedures, bureaucracy and horrible leadership. Situation became 100% better once our department directly started reporting to managers in UK. Prior to 2011, some of my local managers were horrible  and manipulative, they had no clue about management and leadership. Managers in UK were much better, at least they were honest and upfront about career and opportunities guidelines. Basically no bullsh*t.
3. They were pay masters 6-7 years back, now their salary does not match with current market scale.
4. IT in Barclays Singapore has reduced almost 90% in past 3-4 years, if you have been offered a position after 2014 either your team is really required here or your position might be retained only for short time. They have major plans to cut down in Singapore. If you are already working there and it has been only 2-3 years, search for a better job with good compensation. Severance package is good, however, only worth waiting for people who have been there for a while.
5. Promotion process is extremely horrible. You would be interviewed for the position by Senior Managers, someone who has never heard of you might have a say in your promotion depending upon how well you were in interview, it doesn't matter how well you performed in last few years. Even your line manager can't help you sometimes. However, if you have managed to influence people well, you would get promoted easily - you don't have to work hard then. Recently they announced that you could only get promotion only if they have positions otherwise you can't move ahead which is even worse. (However, if there is a position in another department vacant, you could apply for it and get promotion which is better. The catch is most of these positions were in low-cost locations and if you are in high-cost location, you don't have many options then).
6. Due to cost cutting and move to low cost locations, their quality of service has declined a bit.

headline: Goldman does not care about its employees. They say they do, but they really don't.
pros:
Relocation bonus, referral bonus are pretty sweet. 
Great network. Looks good on a resume.
cons:
Pay starts shockingly low. 

360 feedback system is a joke. The firm is focused only on efficiency and the bottom line; they will cut you at the drop of a hat if you're not grinding the wheels.

Layoffs were pretty awful. People just disappeared-- managers didn't say anything before, your coworkers just weren't there anymore, people you cared about and got close to-- gone. Again, the firm does not care. They do not care about you, there is no loyalty to you. 

The hours are long and thankless in ops. 10 hours minimum every day. Never had less than a ten hour day.

Work life balance is virtually nonexistent. You exist to make money for the firm; they do not care about you. 

Management spends a lot of time trying to talk up how great it is to work in ops, but everyone's trying to get out. Ops is where careers go to die; it is the red headed stepchild of the firm. You know how everyone associates Goldman with Wolf of Wall Street types? Well in Ops, you're the one on the other end of the phone when said wolf picks up the phone to scream about a failing trade. It's purely extractive and exploitative. Do not listen to anyone who's trying to tell you that you'll have a long and satisfying career in ops. You'll be strategizing the entire time about getting away to another division, and getting to a prestige office.

In ops, you'll never get the choice of anything. New office building? Nope. New facilities? Nope. Healthier food? No. Central location? No, we're going to put you in the far office. Everything in ops feels punitive.

headline: Sales
pros: Great acquisitions, good theoretical solutions
cons: Management out of touch with rank and file.  The divide grows larger everyday.  Many solutions that seem to solve the same problem, but do not.  Managers always go with most expensive even if it does not solve the problem.  In many cases theoretical or vaporware solutions are sold over existing products with proven track records.  Result, poor customer satisfaction and blemish on IBM.  Very difficult to work within the hierarchy of Sales.  Have not integrated the acquisitions well and seem to lose interest in them after two years which equates to a waste of money.  Difficult to manage the workload and no job security.  Daily talk of RA's which is code for layoffs.  Never felt secure in my position regardless of meeting all my Sales targets and quotas.   The process of evaluating performance is subjective and someone always has to get a poor rating.  Sad for a once great company.

headline: Specialist
pros:
The company provides thorough training opportunities, but to be honest, they are only useful for non finance major students, very basic knowledge that every finance major would have known in college.
The company claims they have great corporate culture, which may be true from some point of view. Colleagues can be supportive sometimes.
cons: Low efficiency in work. This company has very mature and profitable business model, which should be a good thing. However, it also leads to low efficiency and lack of creative spirit (ironically, "creative" is one of the core corporate culture). You always receive warm welcome for your new ideas or proposals, but that's it, no more, just welcome, no followup, no execution. They prefer to do things in the old way. And many proposals and projects that do get into the execution phase are very pointless.

headline: Surprisingly modern
pros:
I never thought i would work for SAP. I came across a perfect job position in a small team without ABAP and since then, my personal few on SAP has changed drastically.

Its super modern with modern Architecture, Tooling, etc. and there are enough other projects/products not using ABAP for Software engineers not liking ABAP.

It is not a startup, so you know your HR is doing a great job and they have plenty of experience. You can actually focus more on your day to day job.


- Job Security
- Salary
- Benefits
- Company Car
- Modern Architecture
- Modern Cloud Strategy
- . . .
cons:
It is not a startup. So things might take longer. Like if you have to figure out who knows how things work.

But no one is pressuring me doing over-hours to get this little thing done yesterday, so i really don't have an issue with it.

Its just that SAP is a huge company and it doesn't feel like a young small startup. I don't mind that :)

headline: A wealth of opportunities and chances to grow
pros: In 16 years at IBM, I was given the opportunity to grow and move into different areas of the company.  I essentially had 5 different careers in that time - mechanical engineering, manufacturing engineering, software sales, technical sales support, and call center operations.
cons: Compartmentalization was a problem.  I never got rewarded for just doing things to help the business move forward, regardless of whether or not it was in my job description.  At times I was even penalized for doing so.  This discouraged "outside the box" thinking.  Also, in a couple of the positions, I experienced upper management setting an expectation of being available/online at night "after dinner, or once your kids have gone to bed."  I hope that is not pervasive.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Working for Deloitte provides you with a ton of experience in such a short period of time. Training and development are taken very seriously and a lot of time and effort is invested in each employee. The perks of traveling add up to free hotel nights, flights, and other reward programs you enroll yourself in. I hear bonuses are pretty amazing and the opportunity for growth is huge. Amazing benefits.
cons: All of the pros come at a price. In my experience, I was traveling to my client site for a year Sunday nights to Friday nights- I was only home for a 24 hour period each week and required to work 7 AM to midnight most nights. I was typically also required to work weekends and was never able to take a single holiday during my time nor any PTO. Specific to my team, I wasn't even allowed to have a say in what I ate for lunch or dinner due to tight timelines- one member of the team would decide where they were going and have to grab lunch for everyone. Even though I was given 5 weeks of PTO, in my entire time there I only used 2 weeks and got a huge payout when I left. The environment is very competitive and not collaborative at all and favoritism is rampant. Some people live for this kind of life and culture and a lot of my team members enjoyed it. However, I value being able to spend time with family, have work/life balance, and work among people who are collaborative and supportive. This was not the environment for me.

headline: KPMG: Partnership of Favoritism

If you do not have a partner protector you are in dangerous waters. I was part of a group that was let go because one notorious partner wanted to get rid of one employee so to cover his tracks he let go of the entire group of 20.
