headline: Never lose focus of what YOU want if you work here
pros: Good pay, flexibility in working arrangement, opportunity for international work experience and travel, deep pockets and opportunity to explore new ideas and approaches.  Good place to work for 2-3 years, especially if you never for one moment forget about what you want to get from the experience and make it happen.
cons: Constant reorgs and regular threatening with layoffs - every 4-6 months minimum the rumors begin, and this has been the case for the past 8 years - can feel like an abusive relationship.  The company is incredibly top heavy, and many in senior positions lack real leadership skills.  The best worker bees can get overloaded quickly, and leave.  Have a sparkling personality and great sense of humor? This is not the place for you - big cones of silence buildings with most working through lunch with their door shut or not coming to the depressing office.  No sense of comraderie.  Total alignment to short term thinking and quarterly plans.  Expected to hit the ground running in any position with little to no training or guidance.  Pension plan long gone.

headline: Every experience is different
pros: There is a certain certainty, that once you are liked by a manager, you will be growing within the firm well.  Each engagement team is different, however, if you are on a big client, you will not have to look for another engagement again.  You always have an opportunity to prove yourself.  HR always will help you if you actually approach them.
cons: Depending on the industry you are in (for me it was NY Finance), there is no work-life balance.  The work takes on anywhere from 10-14 hours/day on average.  Showing face and staying beyond a certain hour, if the manager is still at the office, is an unwritten rule.  Though management will never tell you, they almost always judge your actions.  On many occasions there is a conflict of interest between your engagement manager and your performance manager being the same individual.  Teams that have a certain bond do not tend to accept "outsiders".

headline: Avoid if you can not worth stress
pros:
- Lots of nice people around my age
- 10% discount card given on day one 
- New Store? Some good products
- Luckily this job was just a part time while at college so I didn't care when I quit
cons:
- I was offered the job the day after my group interview a month before the store opened. This offer for the job was obviously not communicated to the store as I had to contact them myself and they had no record of my interview and offer. Long story short had to have another interview!
- Standing up for hours on end, not allowed to bring water in
- Poor wages and paid incorrectly
- Management constantly watch you and comment on your service after every customer
- Even if its your first job management assume you know everything without real training
- Hours were not set and changed every week or last minute
- Hours applied for change, I started with 16 hours which eventually went down to 8 hours. Saw this happen to a lot of full time staff who needed the hours desperately.
- Made to ask every customer to buy more products and even ask for their postcodes
- Dealing with terrible customers but that's typical of all retail
- 'Forgetting' to give proper breaks especially if you are under 18 they will use this to their advantage (I once worked a 9 hour shift and only got 15 mins, little did I know this is illegal)
- Lots of people quitting and finding opportunities elsewhere which shows how bad the company is
- Even though the store was new the equipment was outdated
- No set department for employees, I applied to be a cashier but spend more time in the warehouse, repricing or on shop floor
- Managers sitting around chatting about employees but you get told off if you talk to one another or wait for customers

Overall just very poorly organised everyone couldn't wait to leave and I am so glad I quit. If I was being paid more than £3.79 an hour I would have stayed but for that low pay it was not worth the stress. It wasn't until I found a new job I realised how horrible a place it was to work.

headline: You get what you give - a great place to work
pros: Have a great boss and VP who care for my development and work / life balance. Lots of opportunities for personal growth and the opportunity to travel as well as contribute to different working parties if that is your thing. Always lots of resources to help improve performance with the hotels. Good appraisal system, employee survey, benefits and PDP process that live the ways and values of the company. Global HQ is a lovely place to come to work in with a gym and Starbucks coffee Shop and there is always something going on to communicate our latest brand initiative or when something new comes out. There is generally good collaboration across functions and lots of resources to set out measurements and what success looks like. The most professional company I have worked for with the best guest loyalty program and lots of focussed and well known brands.
cons: We can forget we are a hospitality company. You have to be prepared to network and work across different functions, personalities and manage the self importance of some senior management. The company does not tolerate poor performance but it can take a year or two before you see action and this can be frustrating. Sometimes we don't live our 'Winning Ways' and we create a bubble in our corporate offices that everything is super when we are not always consistent at hotel level. The hotels don't get to see the impact of a new tool or initiative as we can be too busy creating the next big thing. Be prepared to be part of a matrix organisation where it is difficult to turn the ship around quickly and be responsive to our hotel owners and properties when linking in with non hotel facing colleagues.

headline: Leadership that does not lead but grab.
pros: The only pro that I can think of is the fact that you are employed.
cons:
GT used to be a great firm where the leadership cared about the future of the firm and understood the importance of stewardship and the value of building a team and retaining and developing talent.  

Today's GT is different; the make up of the leadership is ex Anderson partners that could not find a job at big 4 after collapse of Anderson.  These partners are now in leadership roles and are trying to get as much cash as possible from the firm to make up for their loses.  They are not forward thinking leaders that posses values and are not looking for best interest of the firm and the employees.  They are individuals that are just looking to fill their pockets at any cost.  The leadership is reactive and constantly changes directions.  Line partners are primarily not happy and are not doing anything since they are too scared of the leadership and in a lot of cases they don't care about anything other than their paycheck.  

The firm is loosing its top talent from partners to managers to seniors.  Looking at the tenure of average employee you will find that majority of people are fairly new to the firm.  The firm has become a revolving door.   There are very few partners left who you can look up to and respect.  The inability of the firm to hire develop and retain top talent and constant turnover is causing a lot of service delivery issues with the client and regulator issues.  The service that the clients are getting is usually inferior to Big 4, midsize firms and local firms.  The firm is a highly bureaucratic institution with little transparency to employees and negative partner growth where partners do not care about the people and in a lot of cases they don't even care about the clients.

headline: Slickly managed reputation; reality much grimmer...
pros:
Since it's the world's largest services firm, you'll find lots of colleagues and there will be many you like. 

The firm clearly cares about its reputation--here on Glassdoor, and everywhere else--so it does all the surface stuff to be well regarded.
cons:
NOT a firm of ideas. Never knows the difference between a good idea and a bad one; an old one and a new one; a valid one and a phony one. Impossible to find actual scholars at this firm. 

ENTIRELY a sales culture. That's what is prized here: selling multi-million dollar engagements, then delivering months or years of ordinary implementation work.

Separately, it is a DO BE culture... Everyone is expected to be polite, enthusiastic, and to evidence a can-do attitude, even when they are being asked to do dumb stuff. This makes it very hard to be constructively critical in any way that leads to growth.

headline: Good place to work
pros:

Nice campus that's easy to reach.
cons:
Salaries, whilst usually good,  vary across the schools/colleges and jobs can often be below the grades they ought to be.

Staff often have too much work to cope with due to a tendency to under staff areas.

headline: Overall, good place to work
pros: Great opportunity to work in various industries and businesses especially for a person just entering the work force.  If you do not know what you want to do right out of college, working for an international CPA firm provides you with the ability to work in a number of different environments.  Plus the training and supervision provided by the company is very good.  You will also find lots of people with a common educational background and similar age.  After you have had a chance to experience different industries, you will have the opportunity to pick the one the interests you the most.
cons: It will take several years with the company before you are given the responsibility to lead an engagement.  So, you may have to bide some time with a lot of tedious tasks that do not require a lot of brain power.  This is especially true in the larger assignments.  I prefer the small to medium size assignments, so that you are involved with more aspects of the engagement.  Plus you will have more interaction with the managers and partners in the smaller assignments.  Also, there may be some periods where the work load is light and that can be rather boring.

headline: Lack of recognition. No motivation. Incompetency of many managers
pros: The only pros I could think of is time off policy. Nobody else on the street gives 25 days of PTO to an analyst. AVPs get 30, and VPs get 35
cons: No mentorship, guidance and support whatsoever. Every man is for himself. Managers are not interested to help you grow and develop, unless you self-promote and 'play the system'. Low pay with no raises for a couple of years. A lot of managers are rather incompetent, so you can't expect any guidance, while trying to resolve an issue or get a question answered, especially regarding the new and growing regulatory environment. And here is an example of a very unique situation: an employee regularly working overtime reports to a manager who is on a reduced work schedule (works 4 days a week), and who storms out of the office at 5:30 PM every day. One definitely can't complain about micromanagement here.

I also feel some managers, even level twos, could do with some kind of training when dealing with staff as they can come off as patronising and condescending, this may just be an issue concerning certain individuals but communication is key. headline: Abysmal management, treat staff unfairly, do not value customers
pros:
Good work once trained if your left to your job
Work with some fantastic people across multiple backgrounds
cons:
Steal holiday pay if your holidays are not put in
Stuck working both weekend days the past 2 years with them 'looking for a replacement'. 
Written warnings for doing things as managers do although they don't get disciplined. 
Written warning for less than a week off over a year although stores absence rate is much higher than my own. 
Changing your shift pattern without contract change, then 9 months later telling you to go back to your contract hours regardless of how that would affect you
Breaching daily rest rule on contracts
Massive lack of staff but forcing more experienced colleagues out of the door.
Telling you that you cannot have specific holidays as they have no cover, yet when anyone goes on holiday they have no cover,
Be given multiple peoples jobs to do including you own.(e.g. work your racking and process it, then take dates off another department, then do markdowns, then work delivery)
Being asked to tidy the shelves when the racking has not been worked all day.
Not allowed to talk to other colleagues on department even if working.

Please note that the recent restructure made the majority of managers redundant (some with over 20 years service at the company) and the ones kept now have to cover sections of the shop instead of single departments

headline: Avoid or at least get a contract
pros:
There are a lot of good, smart people working at DB.
Interesting deals and structures being done.
Still a great name to have on your resume.
cons:
There is an overall culture of bowing down to senior management, like they're kings and queens.  Nobody is willing to push back.  
The ranks of senior management change constantly, and with each change comes a new host of friends and cronies from other financial institutions, each one with their own visions and ideas.  
No single restructuring or idea is given enough time to gestate to see if it will even right the ship.  Before long, the person behind it leaves or is fired / laid off, and then the process starts again.  
Compensation is a nightmare - get a multi-year guarantee or be prepared to get zeroed out when the bank determines it needs cash more than you do.

headline: Product Manager/Strategy III
pros: Oracle is a great place to develop your skills and learn how business works.  They have great benefits and do treat their employees well.  Great training is provided within the company through Oracle University.  I think that Oracle is a great place to start your career, and then maybe 10 years later go back and end it.
cons: The company is so big that it is really hard to get things done quickly.  There is a lot of "red tape" for every process.  Raises are very low.  Even when you do make a career jump into a more senior role, the pay will usually not all come with the increased responsibility or title.  Do a good job of negotiating when you first become a part of Oracle

location: Salford, North West England, England, England
headline: Decent company with issues
pros: Good culture. Colleagues really helpful
cons: Management pressured for results, this feeds down every level so staff always under pressure. Support is stretched and seems to have gotten worse.

headline: Enterprise Architect
pros: Name recognition, 40% market share of the data base market. High pay, good benefits. There are still some very intelligent folks working there, but see below about the departure of the real talent.
cons:
I had fourteen managers within twenty months. Some of those managers I never even met face to face. Most managers only manage upwards, don’t expect any useful advice from your manager. In eight years I may have had one or two managers who had a clue how to manage, both of them were chased away. Negative reinforcement is not a good management technique and drives away intelligent employees. 

The sales reps I worked with were mostly clueless with a few exceptions. Sales managers simply barked at those reps, causing the reps who needed coaching to flail and then fail. I cannot tell you how many sales forecast calls I was on where the managers just berated their sales reps. No help just a beat down. Most sales reps have no idea what their products do, nor do they understand how to sell them. 

I spent eight years at Oracle, never got a pay raise despite service above and beyond the call of duty. A friend who was a manager said that is normal. You are expected to move jobs annually to make more money. 

You must keep track of what you do in fifteen minute intervals in multiple tools. The administrative overhead is really bad. 

Training is a joke, you only get the marketing slide decks, never get a chance to really use the technology you sell. 

Your customers will hate you because the rep before you may have done an audit to them and raped them so they can get a big pay check on the way out the door. 

Lots of arrogant colleagues that care nothing about their customers or coworkers makes this a very challenging place to work. Very cut throat unhealthy workplace. 

The work - life balance at Oracle is a joke. Burnout is rampant. I had two colleagues leave and rather than hire replacements, I was asked to take up the slack, for a year and a half. All major account executives (CADs) are divorced, in the process of getting a divorce, or are terminally single due to their personalities. 

I know I have just written a lot of negative things about Oracle, but I tried very hard to make it work. After eight years worth of honest effort on my part, it was a frustrating experience. My customers loved me, and were shocked when I left, but they all watched what I described happen and all of them understand how hard I tried to make it work. They are happy to work with me again, for another vendor.

- Archaic technology (1 handheld device to do everything, so unproductive especially considering the company is productivity obsessed)
- Treat the lidl Plus app as the saviour to customer service... Maybe reviewing the working conditions/productivity in store will allow colleagues to flourish and provide amazing service.
- Run on a shoe string, staff overworked and will make mistakes

- Health and safety practices non-existent
- Inept warehouse that delivers everything late (impacting customers and also impacting colleagues who then have to rush implementing everything and cut corners) 
- Blame Culture that sucks the life out of your soul

- Not sure anybody has heard of praise?

headline: I love this company!
pros:
Their flexible work environment that focuses on results and not face time or hours is incredibly motivating and is LEGIT.  I work with a team that benefits from this greatly.  Each of us works from home one day a week.  It is the same day so we can plan around it.  Each team takes a different slant on myRyan so they can design what works for them (not be told what works and forced in to it).  For individuals who aren't producing results, they may not get this employee benefit and may have to report to the office every day.   

The pay is unmatched in the marketplace with unlimited earning potential.  Again, this is based on results of the team but, if the team does good work, hustles, and is entrepreneurial (meaning they can make it on their own; don't need to be spoon fed), then the pay exceeds industry standards.  I like to write my own destiny and be control of the earnings potential, which has been very rewarding.
cons: There are growing pains but that is expected.  I have read reviews about excessive turnover of the shared services center and, although there has been some turnover at the VP level recently, it has been for the better.  I have seen service improve and that is what is important.

headline: Extremely long hours. Your co-workers are only in it for themselves.
pros:
- Free food
- On-site Gym
- Everyone will like you more because you work for Google
cons:
- Everyone outside of work won't stop asking about Google
- All of the free food and dessert will make you fat
- Co-workers with a god complex everywhere. They're all at the top of their games with little humility. You will get lonely.
- Minimal chance for advancement
- Everyone is on edge here. No one can relax. You will get lonely.
- My co-worker insulted a Chinese co-worker all the time and no one said a word which is indicative of the culture here.
- Long commute times on the over-packed buses akin to taking two coach flights per day on the smallest airplane.
- Outdated equipment
- Broken toilets everywhere. Broken bikes everywhere. Everything is broken.
- Knowing that this is the best job on that planet makes all of this even more depressing
- The Google exceptionalism mentality permeates everything and everyone here.
- Low wages compared to competition
- I could go on and on

headline: Emotional Torture
pros:
trips to italy
discounts on clothing
show up and leave whenever you like, never have to do a full days work
cons:
I can honestly say YNAP was one of, if not the worst experience of my professional life.
whether it be the rapid loss of skills I experienced whilst trying to work with *really* poorly implemented tech solutions by engineers who have never attempted to implement something before, or any understanding of what problem said solution is there to solve. Managers who haven't considered "why" when choosing a solution and "who" when choosing someone to implement said solution.

You will find that YNAP have almost all the tools you could possibly need, all implemented on top of one another. Except you can't configure them to suit your needs. You'll need to work with something that someone else has implemented with no experience and no exposure to the data you are working with or any willingness to listen to why you want to alter it, or the benefits it can bring.
You'll experience a culture where contractors are treated as untouchable and have built systems in a manner which keep them in a job. Contractors who can happily refuse to carry out tasks they don't consider valuable use of their time or the direction they want to go in. One time I was pulled into a room and asked to justify my position (to a contractor)

I experienced an extremely toxic culture whilst i was there, where every little thing was reported to management, who left me to rot in a corner to the point i essentially shut down by the end of my tenure. I had to take time off ill with stress with bullying and emotional torture common place if you don't fit the bill of who they want.  in my times confiding with other people from different departments, it was reiterated to me time and time again that the experience I was going through was not uncommon around the business.

Their tech stack is just awful! Time after time, I found myself constantly shaking my head in disbelief as I witnessed manually updating files in place on cloud systems, with no version control or audit trail or notification pipelines. Automation tools exist but they are bypassed regularly. IT Security is almost non-existant, with a blanket level of either prod or non-prod access and no granularity beyond that. If you take IT security seriously, this is definitely not the place for you.

There was zero social budget or training budget, I had to open my personal Online Training account up to one of my team, because the level of AWS knowledge was so low in the department and I was refused any budget to enroll him onto Pluralsight or Linux Academy

headline: Awesome or Awful depending on what you are looking for!
pros: Microsoft varies immensely from division to division. The core divisions (like Windows, Office, etc) each hire thousands of engineers. You will spend all your time working on some tiny aspect of one big, great product. If you are cool with that, and cool with the idea that ten years from now you'll be doing very similar work for just a little more money than what you now make, Microsoft can be great for you. It is a comfortable big company with good pay. You'll have decent work-life balance most of the time (again that can vary from group to group).
cons: As an SDE at Microsoft, above average smarts are not really going to take you anywhere. You might end up in a group doing something cool and cutting edge, but your career trajectory and compensation are going to be the same as folks in some mediocre group elsewhere in the company. That can kill motivation over time. Microsoft has become too big and unlike the 90s it is no longer the most preferred tech employer. They no longer get the "best and the brightest". They hire way more SDETs and PMs than they need.

headline: A great time to work for Indeed...
pros:
Great to work with a product that 'just works' for clients when using a combination of the huge amount of free of charge services along with the strategic paid-for products.
A well-known brand globally, and by far the market leader in my region - the  UK
Very nice Central London office.
Energetic and driven team.
Good culture (team nights out, helpful colleagues), great onboarding (Dublin for entry to mid level, and New York for Senior level due to the location of the training talent for the senior onboarding sales programme).
Great perks including unlimited holiday (subject to management approval of course!), Private dental and healthcare, snacks, drinks, catered lunch on Wednesdays, catered brekkie on Fridays, and Happy Hour from 4pm Friday (food, chat and drinks), Apple laptop and more...
Fair pay and good bonus and commission structure.
Disruptive, flexible product, and cost effective for the client.
Continually evolving and growing product range.
Internal opportunities due to arise as headcount will continue to grow over next 1-2 years
Not micro managed
cons: Some back end internal systems need some updating, which will happen...

headline: MyRyan saved me.
pros: I, like many, am a single parent, but raised my child solely on my own. A friend found me a job at Ryan, LLC and it saved me. I had been juggling multiple jobs, to work around getting my son to & from school, and to allow him to have some extracurricular activities. I wanted to be there for him. This company took me on and has gifted me with managing my schedule, giving me the opportunity to be a present mom and a hard worker. In the past job-sharing is what helped people with restricted availability, but did not help if you needed flexibility AND full-time hours. I can not praise MyRyan enough. The founder, Brint Ryan, is a human and he makes you feel human too. For a global company, it has a family feel, a bit unheard of these days. 5 stars, no problem!
cons: Not much room for advancement without a bachelor's degree. In my case, I have spent the time & money available to me to earn my associate's, so my options are very limited.

headline: Work hard play hard culture

Holding a senior position at Bain means being at the epicenter of the most important issues for companies, having a day to day relationship with top management.  Great focus on professional development through formal training and also day to day coaching. Good benefits. It is the most fun and humane strategy consulting firms
cons: It is hard work. You are expected to work long hours, because deadlines are always tight and the expectation is nothing less than first level work. Significant stress

headline: Sinking Ship
pros: Free water - they make you pay for coffee though.
cons: Nobody knows what is going on. Management is schizophrenic.  Turnover is high. Everything is being outsourced to India. Policies and procedures being put into place test the limits of common sense.  Raises are about 1% a year and they delay them at will. There is no room for advancement because people who quit are not replaced.  This leads to the rest of the team doing double the work for no more pay.  Needless to say, morale is awful.

headline: If you need training to learn, this is not the place for you
pros: Access to working with partners and other offices was a unique experience. I learned a lot from being thrown into in-charging audits before I was completely comfortable on the role. This experience benefitted me more than I could have imagined in my next role.
cons:
Morale seemed very low when I left. Veteran staff seemed bitter and overworked so it was hard to get anyone to spend time training or explain how to audit. As someone that learns by explanation, this made working here extremely difficult for me on a daily basis. 

Long hours and lots of travel are required but the lack of training and support I received when I felt like I was in over my head, coupled with six straight months of 60+hrs/wk led me to pursue an outside position.

headline: Truth
pros: Good for resume after 2-3 years with CA/CPA, easy to find another job.
cons:
Terrible office politics. Promotions based on sucking up to the partners upstairs, not based on your true objective performance as an individual. 

No Work/Life Balance - in busy season u'll be worked like a dog till midnight, with no overtime pay, just so that you can meet an arbitrary deadline that doesn't actually exist. 

At ratification meetings, you are compared against your peers, there is a tonne of backstabbing that occurs behind the scenes.

U frequently have 8 different managers asking 8 different things of u. You are always treated like a piece of meat thrown around between all the different managers who only care about their selfish selves and dont want to know about that fact that you have other client commitments.

U are always making up time - if u go on sick day or a volunterring activity, u are expected to make up for the hours u missed even though it was not your fault.

Staffing of jobs is terrible - the charge out rates are unrealistic, they are never recoverable from the client. Jobs are frequently understaffed just so that recovery can look better  for the partner on the job.

U are expected to work on weekends - personal life suffers massively, on top of this u don't get paid.

U are expected to contribute to the firm initiatives even though you are on dirt pay, and there is no incentive to drive the process.

headline: OK place to start

Extensive technical resources..
cons: work can at times be very tedious and can seem endless; hours can extend without boundaries when deadlines come up or when a demanding client/partner have an emergent task--this happens, not very rarely, even just within the months when i was interning. you may feel you work as hard as a consultant, or even i-banker, but certainly get paid comparatively less.

headline: Best Company I have ever worked for.
pros: People focus and career development for those truly willing to go the extra mile.
cons: Nowhere is perfect.  Like any organization there can be politics or people jockying for advancement but typically (not always but mostly) it is at nobody else's expensse (back stabbing, etc.).  Generally your promoted, developed professionally, etc. according to your desire and contribution.  EY takes care of its people but you cant be a slacker which is no different as with most employers.  While your expected to be in charge of your own careen development (in certain respects) you are absolutely given the opportunity and tools to make it happen\.  The careen development and feedback system is very structured and consistent with deadlines, etc..  You also have a counselor and career advisor in addition to your supervisor.  Of course the benefits are outstanding.  They are not ranked in the top 100 company to work for by Forbes 15 years in a row (or so) and business week as the #1 place to start a career by accident. They recognize as a professional services organization your value is only as great as your people.

headline: Happy, fun work environment, head office a little uptight
pros: Has a lot of fun working there, the main thing is that your co-workers are amenable. I was lucky to have hard working  and diverse colleagues as well as pretty fair managers. On the whole they're pretty flexible with hours and scheduling. If someone wants to move up in the business- as my store manager did from the age of 15- there is a clear hierarchy and good workers including myself were rewarded for their dedication and ability. I felt like the senior management respect the value of each individual worker.
cons: Although legal according to Australian labour laws, having to pay for meals at work seems pretty cheap from a company that pays minimum wage. As I was under 16 -the lowest paid- the managers were a little too keen to get me to work every holiday and you have to replace your shift with the same pay bracket. I often felt pressure from the managers when I tried to refuse to replace a shift. Work can be dull and repetitive, but if you're working with good people the time can fly by.

headline: It's a place to start, but don't spend your whole life stuck at McDonald's.
pros: Every day, you get one free meal. Employees also get 50% off all food at their store (you must order inside, not through drive thru). The hours are very flexible. I've gone from working full time in the summer, only every other weekend during school, and back to full time once school let out. I started a year ago when I turned 18. It's a very fast paced job, but the tasks are simple. You learn to appreciate certain things, and it's good place to start off as a young kid.
cons: Of course, the employees (for the most part) aren't the brightest of folks. Some of the managers aren't very well qualified. Rules aren't set in place very well, and you WILL get yelled at - by coworkers and customers. When you're faced with upset/rude customers, you need to learn to not have it affect you. You come home smelling like fry grease, and your feet will hurt from being up and about all day. You're supposed to get a break every day depending on how many hours your shift is, but sometimes you don't get one. Sometimes, business will get incredibly busy, and everyone gets frustrated. You just have to know how to keep it rolling.

headline: Interesting, varied and very multicultural environment but huge bureaucracy and office politics are rife.
pros: The footprint of the firm is huge in terms of market segment, geography, products and services so a fabulous place to learn your trade as an international banker.  If you can maintain your momentum through the ranks then a varied and interesting career can develop into senior management.
cons: Lines of communication are stretched and confused.  The amount of bureaucracy and waste is huge.  The business is prone to drift, stifled by unimaginative "safe" middle managers prone to shuffle reporting lines while maintaining the status quo.  The performance related pay model is broken with disproportionate pay and bonuses awarded to a minority of staff for mediocre or marginal (subjective) achievements at the expense of team performance.  Hence, what happens on a day to day basis in the front line often fails to match the laudably positive and dynamic "vision" statements set out by senior executives.  This can lead to frustration on a number of levels if you are the type of person who likes to make a difference and achieve tangible improvements in terms of profits, costs, service quality, etc. as part of an effective "team".

headline: Typical corporate job
pros:
JPMC is a massive company with so many different areas that you can't keep track of them.  Working in technology is one area can be very different than another area.  I was in an older area that the company had little interest in doing anything with more than simply keeping them running.  So my opinion won't apply to everywhere. 

Pros:
The pay is very good. Generally it can be at the upper end of tech salaries if you have the experience.  But you have to fit in with the manager.  Really, your manager is the only management you'll ever deal with.  Get a good one and life is easy, get a bad one and you'll be miserable.  Movement within the company only happens if you can get in with the manager doing the hiring.  Its all about "relationships".  The jobs are stable for the most part, though quiet, small layoffs happen every so often.  They just don't talk about it.  There are bonuses, and they can be great, but once again it depends on your manager.  Mine was fantastic and gave me great bonuses each year.  Other managers hold that above their employees head whenever there is an issue, and then they'll give out really small ones.  I got about a 10% bonus.  But I spoke to another employee who was being threatened by his manager all the time with his bonus and ended up getting maybe a 3% bonus.  I convinced him to look for another job.  

Another pro is that the company is very diverse.   That's a big initiative and generally works well.

Its not hard to get a job here.  That can be good and bad.
cons:
The biggest issue with the company is the management churn.  My manager had three or four different managers over the course of two years.  It makes starting and finishing projects and long-term initiatives very difficult.  You'd think that managers would pick up where the last one left off, but that's not the case.  Each manager is a silo.  As your go further up the chain, the churn gets worse.  Its not that they necessarily leave, its that they move around.  I think they worst effect is that people are not invested in their area because they know they'll leave eventually.  That means that lower-level managers are the only ones who really work in the trenches.  Talking to them is really depressing.  They know any good initiative has a 50/50 chance of fizzing out.

Siloing exists and is terrible.  Managers are not accountable to one another for the most part.  Upper management doesn't resolve issues between them, nor do they care.  There is no cohesive chain-of-command.  Its very loose and whoever is the most charismatic and clever gets the job done.

HR.  We have an HR?  No, we don't.  Who's my HR person?  I have no idea.  There's someone, somewhere.  Probably not at my location.  Never met a single person in HR when I was hired, nor since.  The internal website is the closest thing I have to HR.

The talent pool is atrocious.  People who have no business in technology are here.  Offshore talent is terrible.  Developers who can barely code get jobs pretty easily.  Why, you ask?  Poor managers, sure, but mostly terrible, terrible recruiting.  Horrifically bad.  Their "recruiters" are offshore talent that have no idea about the job or the location.  They can't schedule things properly, and they can't talk to the candidate properly.  Candidate wants to know where to park?  Forget it.  Directions?  Might as well Google it.  Properly scheduled video conferencing room for an interview?  Good luck even getting a room that has a phone.  The recruiters sometimes get a little belligerent.  Decent talent walks away almost immediately.  Good talent doesn't even bother to apply.  And then onboarding takes months.  Employees show up sometimes without having any sort of equipment on the first day.  JPMC got rid of all the Administrative Assistants, so no one has any idea of who to talk to or what to do or where to go.  Its all handled by some ethereal system in the background.  Want to feel like a cog in the machine?  Work here.  If you're the only team member at your location, then you'll sit there and stare at your cubicle walls for days while things may or may be happening.  If there's an issue, there is little notice and even less done.  It takes individuals who actively chase after things to get someone onboarded.  Hiring someone is utterly embarrassing.  My team has had two people leave almost immediately.

Company culture is fake and empty.  Sure there are lots of initiatives and events and videos and training, but its devoid of real caring.  Its all about optics.  They got rid of the long term people that run the various locations, so the replacements are churners who don't care about making a cohesive group.  Its like a commuter workplace.  People come and go.  Upper management smiles a lot.  The good ones move on quickly.  Pounding sand is the number one activity at Chase.

Morale sucks.  Everyone knows the above issues.  And I had it easier than most.  People put on a fake a smile and try to make things work, but inside they're slowly dying.

But hey, the pay is good, the benefits are decent, and your job is pretty safe.   There's something to be said about not living in poverty.  We often take that for granted.

It seems as though they just hire people off the streets.All they do is stand around gossiping. I hve been yelled at by customers because the managment was to busy gossiping in the back to come up front for a promo order, which you can't do by yourself. I've have been forced to work a rush a few time by myself, including taking the orders,making the coffee/oatmeal, serving the orders off and making drinks and then told off for not doing a good enough job. They are chock full lies and never do what they say they are going to do. The only reason I stay is because I have bills to pay.

headline: EY, GDS - Risk Advisory - ITRA
pros:
-since i was campus placed, this is my first company, was taught to walk and talk in IT Audits
-in the lean season, there is not much work load
-opportunity for travel (within india and outside too)
- opportunity to work in different sectors (internal job postings)
- no strict timelines for coming to office
- women (preferably married) get ample Work from Home
- people here are smart, confident and if you ain't one, you will become one after spending an year or so, i have seen this development in me and others too
-opportunity to grow and learn, due to an enormous employee count, EY organises general training and specific technical trainings
- the yearly appraisal rate is quite good but the pay is least in comparison to the other Big fours
cons:
-during the busy season, work load is too much, and the worst part is, there are different busy seasons in different sectors, if the company wants, they'll put you in each of the busy season, making you busy throughout the year.
-opportunity to travel is given to those, who have been brought up in EY (meaning going from an analyst level to a consultant), consultants hired from outside, have to prove their worth if they want to travel
- internal job postings are there, but very rarely a person is selected, i have not seen one person who has taken some advantage in this
- people here are sometimes too damn smart, everyone trying to become a Tees-Maar-Khan
-office politics, which would result in, people getting good and easy projects to work on, which would highlight their credentials in the year-end performance ratings
-the bonus amount of GDS employees is half from the EY india employees, on the same grade at every level.

headline: The inmates are running the asylum - BEWARE!

headline: Time for change in the industry.
pros:
The programming side of the job was enjoyable.

Paid time-off was excellent in states that prohibit use-it-or-lose-it policies.

The salary was fine, but I was underpaid for my skillset and talent.
cons:
Like many companies, Sage has embraced the open plan office. Like many technology companies, Sage has embraced Agile development processes. Sage uses one of the more popular Agile development processes called Scrum which involves seemingly endless social interactions that constantly interrupt one’s thought process.

Like many people with social anxiety disorder, I found this work environment and the culture that developed around it extremely stressful. I will not go into the details, but eventually I suffered psychotic depression. An unpleasant experience to say the least.

I recently settled a discrimination complaint that I brought through California’s Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH). The complaint was cross filed with the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). The terms of this settlement mean that the merits of the complaint are undetermined by the regulators and Sage doesn’t admit to any violations. As part of the settlement, the company is required to train all California management level employees regarding disability discrimination and requirements of initiating an interactive process to explore reasonable accommodation. In addition, they are required to put up some posters describing California’s discrimination protections. I also received a lump sum.

cons: It's a client service company - lots of long hours, unreasonable deadlines, no overtime pay, and very little work/life balance.  With the current economy, there were no raises or bonuses in 2008, and moral is extremely low.  Many people work for the company and overlook the long hours due to the higher pay rate, but most public accountants actually make less than their counterparts in industry/corporate positions until they are promoted to director, which could take in excess of ten years.

headline: The increasing lack of employee appreciation has caused my enthusiasm to wane.
pros: For the most part, IBM employees are exceptional; bright, driven, hard working, conscientious, productive.
cons: In the years that I have been with IBM, it has gone from a company that seemingly valued its employees to a company that only values its bottom line.  IBM no longer provides money for continued education, no longer provides work-from-home employees with necessities such as printers, monitors, keyboards, etc.  Raises are minimal and do not meet cost of living increases.  Bonuses have shrunk over the years to being nearly non-existent.  Employees work together for years and never meet their fellow department members or managers.  There are several resource actions every year and the employees who remain are expected to pick up the resulting unassigned work load.

headline: Drink the Koolaid @ Apple.
pros:
- Excellent health benefits at a very decent cost. 
- Average to above average pay for position and it was full-time. 
- Work with exciting products. 
- They reimburse you for internet/phone.
- You get a pretty nice iMac to use at your home for job functions.
- Working from home (Can be a con as well, see below)
cons:
- Working from home (This could be a pro for some) as long as you are a definite homebody, if not you will get sick of it fast.
- Management is scattered and clueless, and they are always hiring new Team Manager's instead of finding someone from within to promote.  These people are as clueless about things as new hires are, because they are new hires.
- Everything is very number driven about your goals.  Even the "mini-teams" we had with a leader of each team.  There was at least 4-5 emails per day about something number related.
- To be on the frontier for technology, Apple's internal systems ALWAYS go down, or something is wrong with them.  You are expected to maintain the same customer focus even though you don't have the tools to do your job.  
- While experiencing down time due to system errors, the main system iLog can't track your login times.  Don't expect to be paid for this as I was told I will not be, even though you were working with internal departments to get it resolved.  Work for free!
- You are tracked by aux codes in iLog system you use to help customers. 
- Some people are helpful, but you also have people that don't want to assume responsibility when you transfer a call to their department.  A lot of people are very snobby and have the "big head" about knowing their products.  Most of these situations are people that have been with Apple for several years.  
- The company is experiencing growing pains.  I am very OCD and it drives me nuts how backwards and disorganized the tools you use and the management is about daily processes.  
- Putting in comments and fixing your time card can be a nightmare if you have vacation or sick time to input.  
- Very hard to move into a substantial role within the organization.  Whether you continue to work from home or move into retail.  It's slim to none, unless you reside/work in California or Texas.

-Not allowed on site other than working, so no sociable aspect to the job.

-Exhaustingly understaffed.

-Tips are all pooled between EVERYONE. Including management and as far as I could tell, a higher ratio of them went to the management as the amount received in pay was extremely small compared to how much was personally taken.

-Some clientele are very rude and will make you feel like a personal slave. I can understand this can happen anywhere, however they seem to be more inclined to do it as they are spending money on the gambling side. 

-Management will use the staff as personal waiters, even when busy- not the best use of staff time.

-A good majority of F&B staff are zero hours contracted. Having been one myself and constantly requesting a full time contract due to working over the contracted 40 hours of other staff, nothing was done. Therefore I could only imagine it was either upper management restrictions, or it was simply being ignored. Given this, I can not say there was any room for growth within the company. This was over a period of a year and a half.

-The team morale was so low due to the stress of the job that many did not turn into work every weekend, therefore increasing the stress of other members staff.

headline: Worst company I've worked at
pros:
It's a widely respected company with a good graduate program, on the job training and (in theory) career improvement.

There are free snacks (but not meals, unless you count breakfast at 6AM and dinner after 8PM - I kid you not).

The money is good (before tax!) and there are yearly pay reviews which can be generous if you're fortunate enough to have helped the company out in some way (like fix a disastrous outage) or are especially sycophantic.
cons:
Bloomberg is a big company organised into product silos and where you land will make all the difference to your experience (hence the polarity of opinion here).

You may or may not end up with an idiot for a team leader, you may find yourself working on proprietary systems, completely isolated from industry standards, business practices and protocols, you might be working in a team with no social cohesion whatsoever.

And things can change radically overnight.  The team whose company you do enjoy might need you to work on another project in another team or the boss with whom you have a good working relationship might suddenly move back to the US and a clueless, dogmatic, despotic, company-man appear in his place.

The hours are long and you will find plenty of colleagues, bereft of social lives, who will show you up by arriving early and leaving long after you go home.  Although you will be contractually obliged to work 9 hours per day, expect to consistently work at least 10, many work 12 hours or more.

You might work there for years and never have anything challenging or important to work on.  There is a company policy known as keeping-the-lights-on which translates to if-it-ain't-broke-don't-fix-it meaning the rate of development progress can be slow as molasses.  This is especially frustrating and can be soul destroying for the creatively minded.

Technologically, Bloomberg is incapacitated by decisions made decades ago and its terror of losing market share is tangible.  This manifests as the front-end looking like something from the 1980s but, worse still, developers are forced to use company-specific versions of tools and programming languages, meaning they will not be able to keep up-to-date with modern versions and practices which is poison for career programmers.  It lacks effective testing frameworks and the majority of teams are required to develop, test and release everything themselves, at their own peril.  Some teams do have dedicated roles for QA and deployment but there's no company-wide policy.

Expect to be called regularly at weekends and unceremoniously at 2AM because the network undergoes maintenance every day and anything consuming tick data will set off alarms when it stops arriving.

Promotion to positions of authority is patently based on the Peter Principle and micromanagement and an absolutely obsessive focus on negativity are the norm.  It's well known that the Team Leaders and managers often form cabals so just one of them not liking you could spell game over for your position at the company.  If this happens,  get out before they fire you, and they will - you have been warned.

headline: More like a cult than a software company
pros:
* Great people (at the production-floor level), which makes for a nice atmosphere
* Product is in healthcare, so you feel you're doing something good
* The angry emails from the CEO asking why isn't anyone working unpaid overtime provide some comic relief
cons:
* Below-average salary, and above-average workload
* no benefits and no review process, even though reviews have been promised for over a year.
* the highest turnover rate I've ever seen:
within six months three of the most senior managers have left.
A year on, out of around 20 people I knew who worked in the technology team, only 3 or 4 were still with the company. Only one or two of them counted their experience at Babylon as positive.
* The company does the most egregious use of temporary contractors and offshore development (both India and Ukraine) that I've ever encountered.

But all these  pale in comparison to the CEO, Ali. Ali *is* Babylon. The company is like a creepy cult run by this man. 
Babylon is HIS company, and you're constantly reminded of that.
He will override any and all decisions that he's unhappy with (actual examples: 
team says project will take X weeks to complete. Ali says 'you have X/2 weeks'. Project is completed in X+5 weeks.
The design team says the app's background should be purple. Ali says the background  should be green. 
The list goes on)

Your status and influence in the court of Babylon are determined by how much the great leader likes you. 
Thus we have more than one senior manager who are completely clueless / incompetent about anything to do with their department, but are old friends of Ali's, or are great at taking credit for other people's work, so they get to have titles and influence, regardless of their glaring incompetence.

The culture of arbitrary, senseless, dictatorial decision-making flows downwards from the head, leading to projects being hastily started, frantically worked on, and suddenly dropped at the whim of the head honcho, or as a result of political power struggles inside the junta.

The great leadership tries to compensate for the great waste created by the mangement's incompetence by expecting employees to work more hours, for no extra pay ("a few weeks of engineering can save hours of planning" seems to be the motto).

headline: Important to become valuable to the partner on a client engagement

Good news:  While excellent performance is always helpful, the way to get ahead at Deloitte is to become valuable to the partner and client.
If you get on the right project team, it can be a lot of fun and very rewarding.
cons:
Bad news:  If you become too valuable in a specific role, you can find your advancement blocked by a partner or manager who doesn't want to lose you, so research how potential managers and partners treat their staff people before you commit to a project.
Choose your starting place (function or practice) carefully, because it is very difficult to transfer internally between practices (Consulting to/from Audit/Risk) or major functions (Commercial to/from Federal)

job_title: G E L, Crew, Soon to BE Manager
headline: My McDonald's experience 2.5+ years
pros: Working at McDonald's have its perks. First, working there entitles you to free coffee, tea and fountain drinks. When you're not working and would like a bite to eat at McDonald's, flash your Platinum card and get 50% off meals. Platinum cards also have their perks such as discounts with VIA rail, Apple, Soft Moc and Pay less shoes etc. Most of the time, hard work goes noticed and comes in the form of free food! McDonald's also have a lot of workers therefore there will always be hours if you need anymore than your scheduled shifts such as crew calling in sick or more than expected volumes. It is also perks when you need to give away shifts because most of the time management will figure things out or asking doesn't hurt. Last but not least, you meet tons of people who are a blast and getting by shifts are breeze because we work as a team! Communication is really key for a busy business like McDonald's! Working your way up at McDonald's looks good on resumes mainly because their work ethics and strategies on tackling volumes and projecting products being sold (management wise). McDonald's have Insurance for those working full time.
cons: Make sure you are prepared to walk a ton! There are many positions at McDonald's you may work throughout the day so if you sweat through your feet I advise to have two pairs of shoes ready for extra precautions to prevent blisters. You also may stay at a position for a while maybe 2-3 hours. Positions incluse making drinks ice cream,  running for window or drive thru, lobby, going for parked orders, bun pull, you name it!  For people working at production it can get hot!

headline: Nice while it lasted
pros:
People in the trenches are typically good, loyal employees.  Great brand recognition for paper & tape storage.  Comp is fair.  great location in Boston. 

If you are an efficiency expert and can help improve efficiencies and reduce head count you might enjoy the company.
cons:
Many people in Senior management are in place from acquisitions.  There is too much loyalty to leaders who should have been let go long ago.  (excluding H. Ebbighausen, he is probably the best leader there) Otherwise big old boy network.  

Since acquiescing to the demands of the Elliott Group the company has given up on the Digital growth strategy, or any growth strategy it seems.  Mistakes were made in Digital but could have been fixed.  Marketing is poorly run and grossly under-funded.  

401K contribution limit is low for high earners because majority of employees are not making that much.  Max out around $15K before they have to send your money back to you..

headline: SPOC
pros: Pretty blunt with current direction. Good cafeteria.
cons:
Current direction constantly changes! 

Accounts change daily. Roles constantly change. Bosses change constantly. I feel sorry for every client I talk to because their SPOC, Single Point Of Contact, changes monthly, sometimes weekly. The systems are atrocious. Having to wait 4 or 5 minutes for the reservation system to reserve the next appointment. Uploading documents that are already in digital format are converted to a format that loses much of the original clarity, so we ask the client for the document again and again. We are getting out of the post sales servicing business and having Cenlar take that role over.  Appointments with clients are cancelled for internal meetings constantly.

I saw another comment about the commission award structure changing; yes that's true. Almost everyone in my role makes less then they did 3 years ago. Of course, there's not that many left in our role as they are being eliminated.

headline: A Company that Truly Cares
pros:
I was a bit nervous to work at such a massive, global company. I was worried that I would be locked down to a process and structure. Worried that I wouldn't have the "freedom" to continue to experiment and personally develop my skills.
That has been far from the truth. TR cares about each and every employee, they continue to push the boundaries of benefits and career growth. There are a lot of opportunities to develop your skills, get mentored, and enjoy what you do.
Another great thing about TR, is that if you don't like what you're doing or you want to go to a different division, it is very possible!
cons: With a large company, communication can be a bit of an issue. Listen to the frontline employees and continue to not only put our customers first, but the feedback and needs of our employees.

headline: "Orange Badge" perspective
pros: Location, location, location.  If you live in the Puget Sound area (namely Seattle), are Software professional, and want to work for a Software company, there are few alternatives.  The software business of the Puget Sound is Microsoft.  Microsoft offers the most career choices, the most opportunities, the best benefits... in the Puget Sound area.  Compared to the Silicon Valley companies, Microsoft is decidedly average, but the Puget Sound area is not Silicon Valley.  Microsoft does employ some of the world's brightest people, and the line of applicants at its door is looong, but the brightest people don't make for the world's best company.
cons: I was forewarned on my very first day:  beware of politics.  Microsoft is politics.  Every decision is a political decision.  Everyone treads lightly for fear of lawsuits.  The unofficial company motto might be: "Do The Right Thing" (TM), but --in truth-- it's more of a "For the Love of Bill, Whatever You Do, Don't Do The Wrong Thing."  The decisions which do get made are the safe, conservative, politically correct, decisions.  Innovation is always constrained by the Big Fear:  the fear of lawsuits.  Every discussion seems to be chaperoned by somebody from LCA (Legal Compliance) and no matter how important you are, how smart you are, how right you might be, the LCA is more important, more right.  The very bright people (TM) employed by Microsoft are constantly hamstrung by lawyers, by the esprit d' conservatism, and by the egos of the million other bright people working there along side of them.  Microsoft is like the proverbial Old Boys Club:  everybody who is anybody has been there since the beginning of time.  To get your foot in the door at Microsoft is tough... to lose your job for any reason is even tougher... as long as you don't do The Wrong Thing.  It's easier to keep quiet, do your job, and not question things.  Questioning is definitely a Wrong Thing.  Especially if you haven't been at Microsoft since the beginning of time.  About 25% of people on the Redmond campus aren't even Microsoft employees:  they are contractors (aka:  "Orange Badges").  And Orange Badges, even if they otherwise qualify as Very Smart People" are treated not like second-class citizens:  they are necessary and tolerated, but resented for their paychecks.  Orange Badges are supposed to do their job.  Otherwise they should act the part of a good butler:  silent, halpful, invisible.

headline: Great place to work
pros: At American Funds the compensation is good and you're treated fairly. The culture is relaxed and management is very approachable. They are extremely sensitive about not offending anyone, so if you like to tell dirty jokes at work this probably isn't the company for you.
cons: Because American Funds makes decisions through consensus, it can take a long time to implement a new idea. It can also be very secretive; if, one morning, the person that sits next to you is gone and their desk packed up, you'll just be told that they "no longer work for the company." Don't ask any more questions, or you'll be seen as a troublemaker.

headline: Leadership is a Smoke Screen
pros: Product is fantastic. Worked with some great Peers.

Did not know how to balance obtaining business metrics and providing leadership to the team. The leader could care less about employee growth. STRONG lack of diversity in this company!! Can't believe the CEO continues to receive "diversity awards"! Someone really needs to define diversity for this company. If diversity is ONLY defined as employees outside of the US, then that would be correct. However, that is not the definition of diversity.

The shares tumbled from approx 8.00 to approx 1.50 following a rights issue, the directors made a point to visit each office to encourage the staff to pour more of their own cash into the business all with the caveat 'we cant tell you to invest, but we can say the shares will increase and you will make a lot of money' lies upon lies.

Processes appalling with no training given,  either pick it up yourself or struggle. Pleas for assistance ignored.

location: Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!!
pros: Can do overtime if needed
cons: Honestly, whenever I read reviews like this I always thought oh they’re just bitter or had a bad experience. But I started working there July 2020 in a group of 20-30 and I believe only 3 people have stayed, those people I have spoken to and they are looking for other jobs currently. They have a huge high turnover of staff and they are very aware of it. I have never worked in such a horrid toxic environment. Middle management staff telling you to hurry up when you have to ask to go to the toilet in a group chat of 500 people as you work from home. They are so rude and vile to everyone. The job itself is hideous. It’s a boring easy job which is fair enough but they don’t tell you that you just get abused on the phone 7 hours a day everyday. I’ve never experience mental health issues before since this job. You receive absolutely NO support and even if you ask for help or to solely do emails (as you have to do them as well as calls) they take you off calls for a few mins until the horrid middle management start pushing calls through again. I cannot stress enough how you should avoid to work for this company. Everyone I have spoken to who work for this company has had the exact same experience as me. It is not worth the minimum wage. Even after leaving I have had so many problems with my last pay and had staff members literally laugh on the phone whilst almost in tears trying to sort it out. They are so useless and unhelpful. Whilst working their i received so many complaints from other employees regarding the bully culture and horrible hr team who ignore all emails

headline: HANA Development Support
pros: The pros of this Job is that is it a 9-5, but the hours can be flexible. You never have to take your work home, it's challenging in the sense that there is always something to learn and grow since HANA is such a huge product you can never entirely learn everything.
cons:
- This is an incident type role when you start you get the impression that you are part of development but you quickly learnt that it is a support role. Every day is endless amounts of tickets to solve and you never feel like you are productive because of its a continuous conveyor belt. 

- You will quickly feel the effects of being pigeon holed.

- You don't have much time to work on your own personal development because you are constantly working on tickets.

- Progression in this role doesn't seem to be fair overall, and there is not a lot of transparency in this role.

headline: Brilliant company to work for with fantastic and humble people!!
pros:
Phenomenal development and learning opportunities with a real focus on you as an individual. Over the numerous years I have worked here I have benefitted from working for inspirational leaders and working with colleagues who truly have your back and care.

I have been lucky enough to have experienced several promotions throughout my time at Bullhorn with some roles being created specifically for me in recognition of the fact that not all roles fit all people. This flexibility has really enabled me to fully utilise my skillset whilst providing a challenging and prosperous environment to continue to grow.

The company is nothing without its people and I couldn't think of a better group to work with.
cons: As with most successful SaaS companies and with respect of the staffing industry things tend to move  very quickly so my advice versus a Con specifically would be to be prepared for working within a fast paced environment.

headline: Take advantage of internal mobility
pros:
A multinational behemoth with a diverse range of opportunities and challenges to tackle, JPMorgan touches almost all financial services domains, so there ought to be someone doing something you are interested in, from technology to strategy to product development to operations to compliance. 

Most managing directors are well-rounded and interested in identifying and developing talent for their organizations. 

Once on board, it's imperative to actively grow your network because paths will cross unexpectedly.
cons:
JPMorgan is similar to what Winston Churchill said about the US during WWII, in that they "will do the right thing in the end, but only after they have exhausted all other options." 

From a cultural standpoint, the bank is conservative, so radical changes will take time to implement and low ranking staff will see the need long before steps are taken by senior management to implement the strategy, usually after the competition has tried and failed.

headline: Unprofessional and Poor Employers
pros: Some of the people you work with are ok and they seem to look after apprentices (provide training and support to them)
cons:
They will let you go at the drop of a hat. I was made redundant from them, and was told to leave the very same day!! The feeling was awful as I was made to feel I was fired or sacked because I breached some company rule or policy!
I was told that I could not return to my desk , to collect my things, and neither was I given time to carry out a hand-over with my colleagues!
Also the HR of Kier are very ignorant, ineffective and ruthless. Took me 6 months to get an official letter to say I was made redundant. This was after I had send 20+ emails. In the end instead of contacting the HR person that was meant to smooth over any issues I had after I left (refused to answer her emails), I had to contact the company wide HR Team, whose details I only had because I was a former employee. After several more emails and pushes, she replied and sent out the letter to me!
They handled the situation very poorly and the HR team are pointless. I would not return here if ever the right role came back!
DON'T BOTHER WITH THEM! THEY ARE NOT WORTH ANY ONES TIME!

headline: It all depends on your team
pros:
AC bus facility for employee transport 
Free Sodexo meal card (as applicable)
Amazing infrastructure (including tech)
- this is one area where even some big companies falter but JP has it pat down - video phones on all desks, laptops + desktops and docking stations, teleconferencing bridge numbers for all managers, etc)
Employee engagement programs (Family day, year-end parties, events, etc)
Cash bonus 
No time tracking 
(Comparatively) good food but fewer options
Good employee medical insurance plans (self, family, parents)
20 vacation days + 12 sick leaves
Employee appreciation (RnR) but that apparently doesn’t get considered in the year-end appraisal
cons:
Company-specific:
No work from home option.
Cash bonus which ought to be performance based, is based on everything else apart from that. 
Way too many useless meetings. 
Loyalty to your VP/ED is more important than BAU - keep making them feel important 
Cab drop facility sucks. 
The seating infra doesn’t promote team culture; it’s kinda like call centres (everyone sitting in rows, instead of cubicles); makes collaboration difficult. 

The major reason for my bad experience is the team. I have seen colleagues from other teams who’ve been with JP for a long time (10+ years) and are satisfied. So it all depends on your luck. 
My (team-specific) list is as follows:
Bad colleagues who undermine you so that they look good in comparison
Management who only care about themselves and their image
Appraisals are based on the management’s perception rather than your work (sometimes of people who might’ve spoken to you maybe 2-3 times in the whole year)
Onshore management only care about getting their work done (even if you’re slogging in office for LONG hours)
Based on my above point - bad work life balance and frequent long hours: 12+)
Interview process is bogus. No technical interviews for tech positions (LOL). Anyone who the hiring manager likes can get in, with minimal to no skills.

headline: Agile teams a mess
pros:
Company discount on supermarket purchases
Subsidised gym in London site
Great salad bar in staff canteen
cons:
Company wants to do Agile but ends up doing a horrible mish-mash of Agile and Waterfall
Agile coaches, testing and devleopment all pulling in different direction in their own internal power struggle which negatively impacts delivery
Old manual processes are never challanged so projects are slow, clunky and expensive to deliver
Scrum teams are not assembled at the start of development which mean that teams are forever playing catch up
Internal teams do not even use the same systems to communicate, all of testing on Skype and Sharepoint and all of development on Slack and Confluence
Some departments act like they are part of an independant agency and hold up projects until they are ready to deliver. This is not an Agile way of working
Teams do not have the ability to configure or improve the environments they are working in. So they cannot test out any improvements which would be beneficial to the business
Tech support can take days to respond to requests for configuration changes 
Cloud tech being used in an unstruted way with no communicated ownership

headline: Incredible, Talented People; No Life
pros:
The People. 

So many amazing, smart, talented, passionate people. If you leave the company, you will dream about working with a similar-calibre team again, and you will realize that it may not happen. Treasure it while you're there.
cons:
No life. 

Apple is your life. The high expectations around both output & quality will drive you to do excellent work, but your life will suffer. Add to this the insane hours commuting and you can bid your fun times farewell. 

After a few years of this grind, you may expect to be promoted. Forget about that. You may be able to move up the pay scale, but an actual promotion is a unicorn among cattle.

There has always been an ethical leadership aspect to the culture and history of IBM - granted, it's still big corp, but it's clear to me that ethics and security is important to the cloud sales team. There's a wealth of knowledge, resources, and help that the company is willing to invest in the employees. A great starting point for any career to learn about/get exposed to what else is out there while getting advice from both young and old connections in almost any industry.

headline: Its up to you
pros:
100 year old company, brand recognition and value in market

Work from home policy, in-time - out-time not tracked hence no compulsion of being 9 hours in office

IBM works on almost all the areas such as support/development/testing/research it depends on you what kind of work you want to do.

Good for people who just want to have a regular salary and no hunger to learn new technology, then can keep working in support projects for years together.

Good for senior people, join with a big salary and work till you retirement, no threat of loosing the job in long running projects, your manager wont trouble you given you don't trouble him.
cons:
Most of the work done is support work and  there is not much growth or exciting opportunities to learn new technologies, you keep doing same work for years together and no one will trouble you.

In Bangalore campuses there are not enough seats for people, if a team has 20 personnel then only 15 seats will be assigned to that team, the rest of 5 people will have to adjust here/there/far away in the corner/from home/or in shift.

No free tea or Coffe.

Food is not good/aviodable. Period. Have 5 years of experience eating food here.

Unlike other companies who give some amount of increment to each employee, here it is Nill or single digit salary increment.

headline: Very political and bureaucratic
pros:
Exposure to people and cultures around the world
In many orgs, if you work hard, and show commitment, you can grow your responsibilities and get promoted. 
If you have a strong, supportive manager, things can be great. 
388 Greenwich building renovation, nice new facilities.
cons:
-Ego-driven, political, and very competitive. Many people think more about what a project can do for their career, rather than how it can help the company or team. 
-Teams and individuals compete against each other, rather than market competition. 
-Not enough movement or diversity in senior leadership ranks. People stay put for many years, leading to stagnation in culture and ideas. 
-Extremely limited resources and a lack of prioritization across businesses. As a result, many poor quality work products are delivered, and business goals are not achieved. 
-Many employees are overworked and stressed due to lack of resources and prioritization. 
-Corporate title structure and related power dynamics are a massive culture driver. There isn’t adequate validation of business initiatives. If an MD thought of an idea, it’s taken as gospel.

You would have to get there early just so you had time to go on a scavenger hunt to locate what you need. They also never seemed to have enough staff so if you know how to do multiple positions more than likely they will just put you  wherever they see fit without any kind of heads up (could even be a different department). They never  follow through when you bring a concern to their attention, they also like to have “team meetings” which are more like lashings. They would basically tell you everything you are doing wrong and they liked to  belittle  their employees.  There was often issues with scheduling, they say they are flexible and will work with your schedule but often wasn’t the case.

headline: Lack of Respect, Superficial & Self-Entitled People, Lowest EQ Around Silicon Valley
pros: Well, you might say that it's the on-site perks that are great, but really it's all an illusion because this company operates like the Borg and expects everyone to come in, conform, and become appendages to each other and the company as a whole. Also, having free food at work is nice, if only they offered heart-healthy, diabetic-friendly options. Too bad the campus isn't in a better location -- like a downtown San Francisco one where you at least had other options within walking distance. You can take the shuttle to work, true, but that keeps you trapped in a confined space for a long period of time with other Googlers. Not a pleasant experience.
cons: Does anyone in management or in the company as a whole have an EQ over 5? Forgot any ideas about equality, respect and cultural sensitivity. Also forget working here if you have anything more than about 5 years of experience -- they'll try to exploit the hell out of you and take advantage of any knowledge or experience that you have that isn't part of your job. And they'll bully and harass you on and off campus if you don't give them what they want. Then again, they bully and harass the local community and the local service workers -- the ones who keep the company running on a daily basis, so why would it be any different for someone over the age of 30 who actually has valuable life experience. Not a recommended place to work for anyone seeking job satisfaction of any kind.
