headline: If you're ever offered a job here, run.
pros: For the most part, everyone in the store is friendly and approachable. 25% discount is also a pro :) as is the uniform allowance.
cons:
It's an absolute miracle that Next are such a successful company considering the deplorable organisation of my store. I was so excited to start work at Next and even happier to know that so much emphasis was put on training (or so they kept reiterating during my induction day) but once I actually started work I realised that this was a massive lie. I've been working in Next for a couple of months now and despite asking multiple managers about my 10 shift training programme, nobody has ever started it with me. Unfortunately this means I can only do a few tasks which I can complete quite quickly leaving me bored to death for the rest of my shift. 
In terms of shifts, there are hardly any full time staff which means that wages are absolutely crap for the majority of the staff who are part time, including myself. The store I work in is overstaffed which is obvious on the faces of the staff on the shop floor who are all bored stupid standing around doing nothing/trying to look busy fixing clothes on hangers because if they look like they have nothing to do they get shouted at. There is also a huge lack of communication between managers causing misunderstandings/unresolved issues between managers causing a hostile environment for floor staff to work in.

headline: AppleCare Understaffed, Overworked, Unacknowledged
pros: Most Management is approachable and wiling to work with you. Amenities: bathrooms, gym, showers, cafe's, coffee are top notch. Generous sick leave and tardy policy.
cons:
Unclear Expectations: No clear path to promotions. 

Limited Employee development: Little clear, specific coaching on areas that need improvement. 

Out of Touch Upper Management: -Having the tools to accurately predict and staff for nights and weekends, but consistently not having enough people to address the increased volume of a Service Business that everyone knows has an influx of customers at night and on weekends. 
-Not using those tools to accurately predict need on holidays. For at least 4 years, we spent most of your time not taking calls on Christmas  when other places of business would realize that the volume trend is low enough to let employees stay at home with their families. 
-Making decisions to not hire staff to cover the increased workload of major product changes that would foreseeably increase call volume. 
-Constantly Asking for Overtime on Nights and Weekends to make up the differences described above due to a lack of a desire to hire needed staff. 

-Low Managerial Autonomy. 

Unavailable Administrative and Managerial Assistance: Administrative aspects (Managers, payroll, HR, Scheduling, etc.) of a Service Business with the heaviest workloads increasing at nights and on weekends are administered on a M - F 8 - 5 Schedule.

Managers treat you like kids, there is no room for freedom, initiative and creativity. 

Productivity is the leitmotiv of the company instead of focusing on quality and actual Customer needs. 

Employees are treated the same way unqualified wokers were  in fabrics except that they given fruits and sweets to be able to work even more and faster!!!

cons: The network issues working from home can be a nightmare, The system is dated. They are trying to make improvements but they still have many more to make. I have seen small improvements but the logistics of handling so many types of hardware configurations makes it a slow process and could take many more years than they would hope.

headline: Swings and Roundabouts
pros:
Large organisation with large name clients, can lead to good exposure.
Very good job security especially for Graduates / Entry-level positions
Some great and very intelligent people work here.
cons:
Pay is very low compared to a lot of other names in the industries IBM operates in.
Operates more as a lose bundle of companies held together under one banner than a true unified company with a single vision and strategy.
Partners often never 'put pen to paper' and are often just using IBM as an easy to get into transitional job before moving elsewhere.
Slow progression of both salary and responsibility.
Currently going through a split and focusing purely on a cloud and consulting model - not sure they will be able to compete with others in these fields.
Lots of bureaucracy as you'd expect with such a large organisation.

headline: Hideous
pros:
I really don't think there are any. I guess the fact that you can use the discount at their sister stores COS, Cheap Monday and And Other Stories is pretty good. Wouldn't bother spending the money at H+M though as everything is so poorly made. 
I was lucky enough to have some previous visual merchandising experience, which meant I was given the opportunity to help that team, but people without previous experience weren't offered the opportunity.
cons:
No consideration for part time workers. Given a 20 hour a week contract and told that I had to be fully flexible 7 days a week, which believe it or not makes it incredibly hard to find another job to make up the hours to make the money you need to live. On top of that, they pay minimum wage for the first 3 months, upping to a very generous (!) £6.50 per hour after you've passed your probation. 
I found that people were generally promoted dependent on how long they'd been there, which made for quite a weak management structure at the top and it showed. 

Lots of petty 'punishments' for till errors, which could very easily be solved by upgrading the tills. ie: a customer with 30 things comes up to the till, you scan everything through and then customer decides it's too much money and removes 7 items... You can't cancel those on the till, as any more than 5 error corrects in one transaction gets you a 'cashier error' (you will be called to the office, made to sign a sheet saying you acknowledge you've done a naughty, and be patronisingly talked through the correct process and given a stern warning) .
 You have to void the ENTIRE transaction and start again. Try explaining that to a customer with a screaming kid. (Hint: the 'it's policy' argument doesn't get you very far)

Not paying people for time spent clearing up at the end of shifts is unacceptable. I was once told that I was expected to 'give' at least 10-15 minutes at the end of every shift, unpaid. And that I had to be on the floor 5-10 minutes before a shift started too. If you need us there, pay us. Simple as. 
Also, the till systems are so antiquated it's a joke. And then you expect us to do a stocktake, when the till's don't scan things properly, and wonder why the results are so poor?
ARRGGGHHHH

FOR THE LOVE OF GOD DON'T DO IT 
This is about 1/4 of all the things that are wrong. But I've lost the will to live

headline: If you're robot and you're willing to stick to one group for the rest of your life please join PwC.
pros: It use to be happy hour and dinner but they cut that out mostly. Cell phone plans are covered but thats because they want to be able to get a hold of you anytime. Medical/Dental/Executive health exam is the same as all other big 4.
cons: They want you to be a robot. You're placed in group A. If you want to try out group B then you're doomed unless group B is so shitty that they really need people then they'll let you go. Upper management discourage you becoming a well rounded individual. You have to deal with kiss assers all the time that will throw you under the bus to make themselves look good and please upper management. The firm is made up with people with 0 social skills and no leadership qualities.

headline: The Disposable Employee Factory
pros: They hire some good people. If you must work at home, they will love you for that.
cons: More bad managers than good. Employee development is virtual and done in a vacuum. They cut people rather than retrain them, which means IBM does not value the institutional knowledge required to work effectively in the company. Because the workforce is largely virtual, the collaboration suffers. It is difficult to find new opportunities in different organizations. Being a new employee is difficult. The strategy changes yearly, and is often buzz-word driven. I was there twice. The first time it was the best place to work. The second time... well, I left of my own accord and can't tell you the relief I've felt.

headline: Beware of EY
pros: Just the brand name, that's it!
cons:
There's a reason it is called the worst among the Big 4!
They will squeeze out the last drop of sweat out of you!
Nothing like work-life balance exists.
Weekdays stretch 12-15 hours minimum.
You have to be available at any given point of time. Texts/calls at odd hours.
Most weekends are working that too full day.
No time for personal work/personal commitments.
No social life at all.
All this takes a toll on the body leading to health issues.
Height of favouritism and bias. Chaatu employees obviously are in good books and get an advantage.

headline: Trade Capture Administrator
pros: Work colleagues are all friendly and help to create a good team atmosphere. Ideal for someone who just wants a steady job doing the same things every day.
cons:
Extremely low pay with no opportunities for progression. Management have their favourites and barely look at or speak to you unless you are in their clique. Talented members of staff are continually overlooked for promotions in favour of less experienced colleagues who the line manager gets on with better on a personal level. This causes a high turnover of staff and low morale.

Be aware of the blame game. There is a distinct lack of communication between managers and staff and whenever something inevitably goes wrong as a result of this the managers will do anything to apportion the blame to anyone but themselves.

headline: Tampa Service Center = Glorified Call Center
pros: Benefits are great.  (Good thing they are so good, because you will need more meds to manage the stress/anxiety/depression)
cons: Wayyyy too Corporate Cultish.  Every little thing is 'big brothered'.  After leaving this job, it took me 3 months to shake off the damage it did to my confidence.  Unreasonable and unnecessary load of consultants per assistant puts you in a 'set up for failure' position .  Just when you think you are getting on top of your Inbox, you will have to cover for an absent coworker and get behind in everything all over again.   Should a person have to work at a frenzied pace all day every single day for $39K salary?  A hospital emergency room has less urgency!  I am now working at a smaller company making $50K and assisting TWO executives who give me reasonable lead-time to complete a task ----- not 12-15 people jamming your Inbox every night as they work until midnight.  EVERY SINGLE meeting you schedule will get rescheduled, many of them MULTIPLE TIMES.  Someone tell the Partners about the idea of respecting others time and honoring appointments --- the Partners constantly backing out are causing massive re-work and CHAOS out there.  Four dimensional calendars?  Come on, people.  How about this fun workplace practice:  Your supervisors will strategically plant themselves near the elevators at 4:55pm to make sure no one is leaving early.   Great job, guys -- you're really on top of the big problems around there -- employee time theft! (eye roll).  If anyone is stealing anything - McK is stealing LABOR with their terrible pay rate for the output expected from one person.

headline: Lack of Opportunities in MS Wealth Management Capital Markets
pros:
+ There's been some great people I've met after starting my career on Wall Street over two years ago.
+ Learn a variety of capital market products within a year.
+ If you live in CT or Westchester, the commute is ideal.
+ Nice gym for $15/month
cons:
- The managers of this 300 person operation recruit smart Top 20 College seniors to positions promising an opportunity in "Sales and Trading" at Morgan. This could not be further from the truth:
- No client interface. You are told that your clients are Financial Advisors, who actually 'own' the client relationship. They block your ability to pitch ideas directly to clients.
- You often become a help desk/support for these Advisors. Need to know how to set up a printer? Call MSWM Capital Markets. Often you may have various trade ideas ready and waiting, but get too bogged down in the help desk function of the job to even get a chance. 
-Pay is awful for the work.  Despite having to work 12 hours/day and deal with 2.5hr commute. Associate pay is 30% below street average. VP pay is at same level as analysts at other firms.

headline: Good company losing its way
pros: Great customer focussed culture. Good program Managers who really try to do a good job.
cons: Company is in steady decline.  Revolving door at Senior Exec level, and they just keep bringing in outsiders to do the same old thing.  Keep losing business which leads to cuts in overhead.  But Senior Exec stays in their palace on the 10th floor.  Nobody really has a vision how to grow the business.  They keep talking about accountability, but this does not apply to the 10th floor, just those who work for them.  CEO is out of touch, not everything is a process.

headline: Getting worse all the time
pros: I've always been happy with how flexible the job has been.  If you need time for a doctor's appt or something, you just take the time.  No one is looking over my shoulder or tracking anything.  Working from home is an option, and also flexible.  I've also had great teams, and most of my managers have been good.  Overall it has been a positive experience.
cons:
Salary - very poor, not competitive with other companies, and getting worse as the Burlington fab has been the anchor on Ginni's plans.
Morale - yearly layoff's have taken their toll.  Nearly everyone I talk to is grumpy and pissed at IBM.  It's really made it an unhappy place to work.  I used to enjoy my job, now I'm mostly putting in my time.

headline: Customer Engineering in Cloud
pros:
Learning a new platform and Google-specific tools
Developing great industry relationships and the ability to present to a group.
Your peers are great, smart and usually nice people.
You'll learn a lot about cloud sales. 
Google has a great brand.
cons:
You have one main manager and a lot of dotted lined stakeholders for your role and they don't get along.
The promotion cycle is impossible, you need buy-in from many levels of leadership who dont' know your work.
You'll never up-level unless you're severely underpaid. 
You're not technical and success is a popularity contest.
There are a lot of new, very senior managers who don't know what they're doing.
The organization changes constantly and you might be stuck working on things you dont want to.
You have to sell the Google-way of doing things.

headline: Worked for the company for 13 years in total, has seriously gone down hill since the Dixons merger.
pros: The people you work with and the discounts on airtime contracts.
cons:
Unreachable store targets, not customer focused anymore, consultants pushed to sell higher more profitable tariffs to make more money from a sale, even though customer can get a cheaper deal. 

Senior management all from Dixons now, original carphone management forced out of the company. 

Even the carphone warehouse website is taking deals from its own stores. 

Poor equipment in all branches, still using a computer system from the 90’s which is insecure and unreliable. 

Such a shame to see this company and where it is now. Bring back the five fundamental rules the company once prided itself on and look after your staff! If someone sells an £1,000 handset on a £68 per month tariff pay them more than 25p.

headline: The fall of the empire
pros:
- Hires young, bright resources
- A few really great managers/senior managers
- Amazing culture in the past - this still resonates with some managers/teams, but not all
- Analyst program is incredible - leaders, coaches and participants all enjoy and come away will great skills and networks
cons:
- Confusing and compressing compensation structure for FY13 and beyond, places all the risk on staff and away from partnership
- Opacity into firm earnings (and what they mean, e.g. "making plan")
- Inability to rotate between projects and get diversified experience
- Many "checked out" senior managers/PPDs, no mentorship at the highest level
- Lots of overhead staff watering down the culture and profits
- Many 'experienced hires' with no relevant work experience brought in at too high of a level in the PPD track
- Top heavy with nebulous edicts from HR organization that no one can request information from or make changes to, absolutely no personal care or attention paid
- Forever changing "road to partner", 10-12 years to 15+ years in my tenure
- Role of 'counselor' has no control on it, many counselors are unknowledgable and unenthused

headline: Super corporate
pros: Has fun culture initiatives, fair pay
cons:
Confused management, no opportunity to really make your voice heard, especially if you're lower level. I worked in the marketing department, and was constantly frustrated. From vague performance reviews (so they don't have to give you a raise), to clique-y groups, to boring design monkey work (I was a graphic designer). If the Partners say jump, you need to say "how high?" no matter what the request, even if it meant turning out a bad project. Questioning "how things have always been done," was DEFINITELY not allowed. 

Work/life balance was awful. People in my department regularly stayed until 7 or later, so much so that when someone tried to leave at 5, they weren't considered "dedicated enough to the company." Once you got home, you were expected to be online, if not working, then on call. I worked many, many, weekends, once even missing my husband's birthday. 

Opportunities for advancement were minimal, and the marketing direction has changed several times in the last few years, with extremely high turnover. Mass firings were the norm in my department, keeping morale low. 

Extreme lack of diversity. As a person of color I was one of maybe four POC in the entire building who was not in an admin role.

Overall, one of the worst jobs I've ever had.

headline: Deloitte as a whole is a great place to work.

The networking that Deloitte can bring is huge, as are the opportunities to see the world.
cons:
The money wasn't worth the painstaking efforts that so many put forth.
Depending on whom you were working with professionalism was overlooked.  There are some people that are great at being managers and others that are great at mentoring.  There are also others that can't do both and the mentees are the ones that suffer.
If you do decide to transfer to another office, be for-warned that you may be required to come back to your originating office when that stint is done.

headline: Hilton's IT has succeeded in taking disorganization to a new level.
pros:
Hilton has a team member travel program that allows employees to stay at Hilton properties at discounted rates.  Although I have never once been able to get an "Employee" room at any hotel without personally calling the hotels general manager, it is possible to get "Family" rates which, although they are not free, are discounted from the properties normal nightly rate.

Depending on what projects in IT you work in, there is some opportunity to work with some of the latest Microsoft technology.  If you happen to work of one of these groups there are some really great toys to play with.
cons:
Hilton's corporate offices are very bloated with middle management.  Layer after layer of bureaucracy that impedes the company from making any real progress.  The Blackstone Group, who now owns Hilton is about to make a massive round of cuts and in the near future this may no longer be the case.  Only time will tell.

Corporate as a whole, has little or no project management processes in place to allow projects to be managed effectively.  In most instances projects are successful in spite of themselves.  If you can stand the utter lack of organization and the mind numbing bureaucracy, Hilton will be a fine place for you to work.

headline: Work at home but still no life
pros: Hotel benefits are pretty great, you get to work from home, that's pretty much it. This is a short term type job rather than a long term career choice.
cons: If you work full time you will never have a life. Always working weekends and requesting time off is not always easy. The hotel discounts are good but finding an available hotel is very difficult (don't plan on staying anywhere on the weekend cause it wont happen), turnover is high with supervisors and they only care about the big picture which is expecting way too much from agents with each call. They also do not like if you have to take medical leave or maternity leave which resulted in a lot of people not coming back after taking leave. Your experience also depends on who you work under. Some supervisors are great and appreciative of what agents do, others barely give a "good job" when you meet all of their ridiculous expectations. Working from home is nice, however their virtual system is constantly having issues, calls get dropped, system freezes and requires you to reboot your entire computer, programs that we use do not work. Even though the issues are on their end they expect you to still be able to work through it, and if it happens enough time they will fire you without warning for having too many issues, even though the issues are on their end. Pay starts low and with yearly raises you would still have to remain with the company for a long time before making a reasonable wage. Full time employees get to bid on a schedule every 6 months but its based on seniority, which means if you've been with the company for less than 3 or 4 years then you'll most likely get a terrible schedule. Work/life balance is also awful and don't even think about getting to spend the holidays with family if they are out of town/state. Also if you ask 3 people the same question you will get 3 different answers. And the hotels are not on the same page as the call center so you get a lot of customers that were told conflicting pieces of information and finding the right answer takes forever....then you get penalized for that.

headline: Flexible Environment, Growth Opportunities
pros: Our company has something called MyRyan, a flexible work environment that if enforced by management is a great thing.  It allows you to work when you want (within reason) and where you want.  I, personally, get a lot out of the 'where you want' part of MyRyan due to life circumstances.  this is something I don't think I could find at many other companies.  The work is constant and I feel stretched in a good way.
cons: The pay is a little low, but with bonuses it is possible to have a great annual pay.  Our work environment is fine, but I wouldn't say it is on the cutting edge of facilities.

headline: Onboarding and first 6 months
pros:
- Amazing culture from transparency to giving back to developing people
- I was given ample time to ramp up on the knowledge I need to do my job
- Fast-paced, always changing dynamic product and go to market approach
- Work / life integration is truly a value between time to volunteer to ability to spend time with friends / family around work
cons:
- As most people are Remote, need to be comfortable with that setup and the lack of interactions.  It is offset by plenty of video conferences
- Really not a negative, but there are so many great people career progression will take time and not be overnight

headline: Great benefits but are deceiving
pros: Great Benefits, lasting relationships with people that can be friends, can be easy to do task that does not look at your education, has training opportunities
cons:
Overworked, low bonuses, hard to transfer to other offices, hard to transfer to work worldwide, too much red tape, training opportunities ONLY favor certain line of individuals, too much politics, so many to name. Here is my long story:

I started at Deloitte as a Associate level now known as Project Delivery. I had about five interviews in one day and I highly prepared for it, but it was nothing like a case study it was more like a typical interview; strength, weaknesses, why should we pick you and etc. Later I was talking with a PPD about my salary and what I should earn. I negotiated as best as I could but had no other offers, so I was low balled. I was hired and satisfied. 

Coming orientation day; they gave me the wrong address and I ended being late. Really nice :-/. Anyways I was lucky to be staffed as many people were just entering the firm with no project. The orientation promised all these things such as training opportunities, Deloitte University, be able to travel, be able to move to other offices, and be able to work worldwide. While yes these are all true it's ONLY for some. Everyone does not get these opportunities. I only found out later that these were just ways to make people "excited." 

My first project was a nightmare; management treated me like total garbage. Between the words I was worthless, not learning any skills and I would fail. They actually set me up for failure. When I finally was told to roll off I had to go to ethics as they told other projects not to hire me because my counselor at that time was best friends with the PM. It was really petty and disgusting that they wanted to ruin my career. I fought back hard and won and I was able to find a project more comfortably. I would say it was a long fight and prepare to be stressed if this ever happens. I had to talk to several offices, people, and had many countless nights of no sleep because I really thought my world was crashing down. I found out later the PM an assistant manager was having relations in the office late at night and during the day as someone I knew caught them in the act. One of the managers still works at Deloitte today which I find very troubling. 

Finally another project hired me and I am still with them. They can be a great set of people but so many manager shifts that it makes it tiring at times. Sometimes management just makes excuses to not let you obtain your goals and tons of red tape. 

Associates became project delivery analysts and I have been stuck at this service line since I been hired. I been wanting to move out but there are so many rules and regulations that I always get rejected or hear another excuses. Project delivery people cant go to Deloitte University because we have to be 100% client deliverable; we do not get bench time either. Yes its a very predictable schedule but very hard to grow as a person. They want you to stay at your same role for long periods of time and they do not really like you to even move around lie consultants or specialists are allowed. 

My last opportunity was a disaster as new people were hired and took this project I wanted to join. This would have been my way to switch tracks but of course Deloitte gave them funding and I was left in the dirt. Its unfortunate that people like this get to move up while throwing others under the bus. 

Overall: It has great benefits and training opportunities but only for some. Others will not be able to grow and management can actually be helpful at times but Deloitte is filled with so much red tape it's discouraging. I feel at my age (which I am in my 30's) that I am stuck and do not know my next move sadly.

headline: Avoid if you are being hired into a 'specialist' role
pros: Very smart colleagues, central location, one is encouraged to stay in fancy hotels. WLB proposition generally works, most specialist folks don't work overtime.
cons: Speaking from the perspective of a specialist role: complete chaos, management changing directions all the time, no career track, below-market salary (where the market is other big American companies operating in Germany). Cramped open-space offices with someone constantly talking to a client, making it impossible to concentrate. Nobody has any clue how to integrate recent acquisitions, partners commonly see developers/designers as fungible "resources" ignoring any team dynamics or geographical aspects, so that three developers in the same office can easily work on three different projects (bonus points if some of them are the only remote team members). Projects themselves are mostly not about innovation but rather about saving established companies from being overtaken by more efficient firms, where the client company is typically quite dysfunctional (as it seeks help of OW) - which means the projects are rarely on time / within original budget.

headline: Good pay / same job

cons: The same job forever. Very difficult to move because no preference is given to the internal candidates. Promotions are only in R&D, the rest of organization does not see any. Each time they post position - they bring a pool of external candidates. Managers do not promote their employees unless you are in R&D. I have seen people stuck for 10 years not being able to move even though the company is huge.

headline: Amazing Company, Passionate People
pros: Core to their belief is believing in patients. Each local site may have different cultures but they all work together to drive Roche's mission. Diagnostics and Pharma divisions are pretty different from one another. I specifically worked at Roche Molecular Solutions, which is made up of three different business units. Each business unit is unique in its own way, with its pros and cons, but it seems like management has a good vision on what they want to do with this
cons: Roche sometimes make confusing decisions without explaining why they are to the employees. It is what happens in any large organization but can get frustrating at times.

headline: Iconic brands being led by idiotic and chaotic leaders
pros:
Base pay is very competitive for the midlands. 
Health care plan is best in class.
Depending on manager, flexible and agile ways of working.
Empowering roles (but process and politics mean it’s hard to actually deliver).
Trying to improve employee experiences but very inconsistent.. 
Strong safety culture, especially in Manufacturing.
cons:
Difficult place to be in many ways. 
Parking - difficult 
Getting a desk to sit at comfortably for the day - difficult. 
Getting stuff done and delivered - difficult (if you’re prepared to fight every day for progress then you will eventually make change happen).
Giving feedback - difficult (folks are very nice to each other but lack the bottle to have difficult conversations).

Total compensation is not competitive - bonus payments have poor in recent years due to unachievable and ego led targets (yet the CEO will still take home a hefty sum).

Workplace standards are still very poor in some locations. There is no glamour working in this industry, the gloss of the product is not reflected in working environment. 

Some key teams and functions lack experienced leaders leading to poor decisions and chaos. 

Progression and promotion will be down to a ‘face fits’ approach rather than fairness and transparency. 

Production and product will always come before humans (unless serious harm is likely). Some basic human needs are often not met and production associates are treated poorly. 

Worst of all, the product is poor quality. It looks great but it is pot luck if a customer managers to go 12 months without a breakdown call out or a trip to the dealership. 

Forced shut downs.

headline: Good perks, variable job happiness
pros:
Good benefits, especially family leave
Opportunity to travel to Italy and France if on product-focused role
Italian lessons
Discount/ sample sales
Innovative
cons:
Certain departments have morale issues. I was based in supply chain, where significant staff turnover and budget freezes led to overworked staff. Better salaries can be found in LVMH and Kering groups for the same conditions. Plenty of  colleagues left to competitors.

Non-technical consultants recruited from Deloitte tend to be promoted quickly. There is a strong salary difference between technical and non-technical staff.

Some managerial staff are on record for bullying staff and I know of one with multiple sexual harassment allegations. The HR dept did little to address these issues.

headline: Stimulating work but ineffective people management
pros:
Stimulating work and genuine opportunities to make a difference to customers' lives.
Diverse mix of ages, ethnicities, background and life experiences amongst employees makes it a dynamic and interesting place to work.
Good rates of pay and very good benefits packages.
cons: A silo mentality and cumbersome structures/processes exist in large parts of the organisation which hinders its ability to be agile and "joined up". There is a surprising lack of understanding in the organisation about how to really motivate employees and empower them to do their best work. The performance appraisal system was ineffective and did not reward those who worked the hardest or made the most impact.

headline: Not so bad, but far from being great
pros:
Great benefits
Friendly colleagues
Nice office
However that's about it. It really depends on which office you working at as some offices have horrible management which makes it even harder to come to work each morning.
cons:
Management is not supportive, would never help with anything, most of the time even demotivates you. But there are also very few people who can help but rare to find them.
In most of offices there are zero career opportunities so not many people last more than a year. 
It's all about visibility and with whom you are a friend and who likable you are. Most of the manager don't do more than just have meeting which no one knows what they are about or spend the day on Facebook at work.
There's lack of communication across the company, not many people know what they are doing including management. 
I believe there are much worse jobs out there, however I would definitely think twice. Few years ago this was a nice place to work, but with all the cost cuts, huge staff turnover and management it became a place where not many people want to be. 
Be prepared to spend 8h per day on the phone arguing with people who cannot read, unless you are on a language line which is closed and receives only emails. If you are looking for a job and need money go for it, but if you looking for a career or want to progress than rather choose something else as that's not going to happen unless you applying in the head office.

headline: Customer relationship manager
pros:
Senior managers are very approachable and know what they are doing.
Work is very easy and has on site car park.
colleagues are great.
The working environment/office is very good.
cons:
Low pay.
Your just a number added to there 66000 other employees.
A lot of team managers are shockingly bad and care little about the client/customer and only on targets. Which is poor because Capita is an outsourcing business and supposed to treat the clients customers as if there own.  Instead they ignore compliance concerns and possible complaints in favour of what is least amount of cost to Capita.  Irrespective if it was Capita that created the compliance issue it is put under a carpet and ignored.  If you raise an issue as you are told to by senior management your TM takes a dislike to you for highlighting the issue and so he has to actually do some work.

If you have ideas they are ignored, even if they are really great and can save both employer and client money.  Team managers do not like those below them outshining them. 

Daily constant IT issues.

Half yearly 121s are a joke with ratings from Team managers based on perception and not facts.

Not for free thinkers or those who want to do well and want a challenge.  If you have a moral compass then avoid Capita

Overall the senior management show good empathy and seem to care about the core values, the issue is that team managers do not follow in the same way as the message we get from higher up.  Instead doing as little as possible with minimal effort.

headline: Cover manager in Calderdale area
pros: Good hours of work ie can finish early when the DOM has left the office, however mainly based on seniority of which manager goes home first. Varied role with extensive people management by managing challenging posties. No Sundays to work
cons: Have to work every Saturday. Other managers in this office get preferencial treatment from the DOM. Bullying culture, just a numbers game, managers spend most of their time out delivering post rather than managing. DOM managers by threats but does not follow them through. Upper management are aware of this however not reacted to this. The posties work hard, however be good if they are recognised for this.  Other managers leave early on Saturdays and during the week so not work full contracted hours- which a really good perk to work for Royal Mail

pros: The job itself was fairly easy.

headline: Decent benefits and pay but undergoing a difficult transition
pros: Decent benefits and pay.  Many opportunities to work from home if you prefer that situation.  Good training available to all employees.
cons: IBM is going through a difficult transition in the IT industry.  Parts of IBM are growing revenue and parts of IBM are losing revenue.  In recent years, this has led to yearly 'resource actions' where large numbers of employees are laid off in the parts of IBM that are losing revenue.  My experience is that IBMers struggle with work-life balance.  If you are in the part of IBM that is growing the team is always understaffed so everyone is working OT just to keep up.  If you are in the part of IBM that is losing revenue, headcount is cut so deep the few remaining headcount are doing the work of multiple people or constantly training off shore resources that seem to turn over quickly.

headline: Fast paced, driven environment.
pros:
Company is huge so there are a lot of internal oppurtunities  to expand your career. Company also uses almost any kind of IT technology out there so if you are  a technologist there is ample oppurtunities. Corporate culture varies based on which LOB you are in,  drastic differences from fast paced to very relaxed environments based on which LOB / business unit you belong.
Company CEO is very dynamic and straight forward and projects a leadership role.
cons:
As with most companies this size there is a lot of nepotism  and old boys clubs.
Power plays constantly happening from NY, constant strategy changes of centralization of IT and then decentralization. Lots of bureaucracy and due to that bureacracy lots of middlemen paper pushers with power.

headline: Working at National level
pros: Great properties, Lovely staff in the hôtels, lots of good benefits
cons:
At a national level - working in sales for Macdonald Hôtels, I can honestly say that the atmosphere is one of the most toxic I have ever worked in. 
Whilst I may be dismissed as being a bitter ex employee, I have talked to many other people in the industry who have had a similar experience to mine within the company.
 Senior management in Macdonald work by fostering an atmosphere of fear, intimidation and bullying to get results. It is a real shame as there is so much potential for this chain. Unfortunately the culture of intimidation starts trickles down from the family members at the top of the tree and you will only fit in if you adopt the same approach and become a bully yourself.

headline: Once A Great Company, Not Anymore. Such a shame.
pros: The company offers discounted services through MyRates and discounts for family and friends through MatesRates. The people are friendly and helpful.
cons:
Over the past few years the gateshead department, and the company has rapidly gone down hill. Gone are the days where the customer is at the heart of everything and it is now all about increasing revenue generated from a customer. Targets are based on how much money you can get out of a customer and there is no focus on customer service. Staff morale is rock bottom. After speaking to staff throughout the business, this practice is now common place.

Management do not seem to care anymore, and do not seem to care about low morale, or the loss of experienced long term staff. It's not what you know but who you know when it comes to progression. There has been a mass exit of long term, highly skilled staff who have simply had enough. The company is branded Virgin but thats where the Virgin Values and Ethos now ends. 

Where most companies are investing millions in improving customer service to be the best, Virgin Media is massively lagging. It is such a shame as I used to be proud to work for such an amazing company, but now its quite embarrassing.

headline: Great people, reactive environment, tiring hours
pros: The people at Oracle, whether in the US or India are bright, professional, reliable and hard-working. Salaries are good. Benefits are very good.
cons:
Work-life balance was inadequate when employees were required to put in 8 hr days and then get back on-line at night for meetings that often ran until after midnight and then required team members to stay on-line afterward in order to complete work assigned that night and due the next morning.  

Processes changed with each release which made it impossible to measure results for process improvement. The reactive environment was indicative of a lack of realistic resource planning or an inability to use that data to manage task requests from upper mgmt. 

Employees sometimes waited years for raises due to an aggressive acquisition strategy.

headline: Not a good diverse company
pros: Nice downtown Baltimore view and also laid back at times.
cons: They barely hire any minorities, last summer none of their intern was a minority, even though the company is located in downtown baltimore. I guess no Asians, Indians, African Americans, or  Hispanics are interested in working in real estate. When they hire 1 per 100, they are left to feel uncomfortable. A lady in property management always referred to African Americans as "they",  and how she doesn't like driving in "their" neighborhoods.  She said "they" are always killing each other and doesn't want to get caught in the middle of it. You know, appropriate office conversations. She also always touched an African American girl's hair. She doesn't even ask, making the poor girl from a local high school feel very uncomfortable.  You don't touch African American people's hair! it is a real estate company,  not a salon.

The work-life balance is pretty good there too - I was in to work on a few weekends and I don't think I saw anyone else in the office.

There's a mixed bag of management that is reasonable & supportive vs work horses. It's the luck of the draw and the ball is in your court to speak up if things are not going the way you like and often times, there is no one around to listen.

headline: Google is a great place to work as an engineer - just don't expect a small company environment
pros:
Google is one of the first places I've worked where I feel like I'm surrounded by people that are way smarter than I am.  This makes for a really creative environment, where everyone is pushing you to go beyond your limits and make something even better.  It also means that you can just trust that everyone around you is really good at what they do.

There's also a huge focus on only launching things when they're ready, which, as an engineer, means when something does launch, you're really proud of it, and don't feel like it's half-assed because you were rushing to a deadline and cut a lot of corners.

Oh, and the free food and benefits rock, but they wouldn't keep me at any job if I didn't enjoy the work and the people.  But when you do like the job and the people, they make it that much better:)
cons:
Google is getting big.  This means a couple things: It's no longer always a "startup" feel.  There's a lot of teams, and a lot of infrastructure, and there's starting to be a bit of bureaucracy here and there (though management has done a pretty good job killing it on sight whenever they see it).

Also, because we have a lot of users and are always in the limelight, we have to be really careful about launching things, which often means that launching something requires jumping through more hoops to make sure it's scalable and stable, and that all the i's are dotted and t's are crossed, in order to not have a bad press situation or an emergency caused by an overloaded system.  This is good for production launches, but can slow down experimentation in the early stages of a product.
